analyzed: spyod pa la bya bas na mya ngan las 'das par bya ba'i phyir spyod pas na tshangs par spyod pa zhes bya /
translated: to act. Thus, since one acts for the sake of nirvana, it is called pure conduct.

original: a'a doo ka ly'a na zhes bya ba a'a doo ni dang po yin te tshangs par spyod pa'i dang po la bya /
analyzed: a'a doo ka ly'a na zhes bya ba a'a doo ni dang po yin te tshangs par spyod pa'i dang po la bya /
translated: Adhi means first, referring to the first stage of pure conduct.

original: kaly'a na ni gser bzang po cir yang bcos shing brdung du rung ba dang 'dra bar yon tan gyi rim pa gong ma kun gyi snod du rung bar 'gyur bas na dge ba la bya ste /
analyzed: kaly'a na ni gser bzang po cir yang bcos shing brdung du rung ba dang 'dra bar yon tan gyi rim pa gong ma kun gyi snod du rung bar 'gyur bas na dge ba la bya ste /
translated: Kalyana means good, like good gold that can be fashioned into anything and beaten without being spoiled.

original: spyir na dang po lhag pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pas dge ba thams cad kyi gzhir gyur pas na thog mar dge ba zhes bya /
analyzed: spyir na dang po lhag pa'i tshul khrims dang ldan pas dge ba thams cad kyi gzhir gyur pas na thog mar dge ba zhes bya /
translated: In general, since one who possesses superior ethics is the basis of all virtue, it is called the first virtue.

original: ma dhye kaly'a na zhes bya ba tshangs par spyod pa'i bar ma ni bsam gtan bzhi la sogs pa sems mnyam par @143b gzhag pa'i ming ste /
analyzed: ma dhye kaly'a na zhes bya ba tshangs par spyod pa'i bar ma ni bsam gtan bzhi la sogs pa sems mnyam par @143b gzhag pa'i ming ste /
translated: Madhyekalyāna means “middling in terms of pure conduct.” It is the name for the four meditative concentrations and so on, which are mental states of equipoise.

original: lhag pa'i sems la bya bas na bar du dge ba zhes bya /
analyzed: lhag pa'i sems la bya bas na bar du dge ba zhes bya /
translated: Since it is an action related to superior mind, it is called “virtuous in the middle.”

original: parya ba s'a ne ka ly'a na zhes bya ba tshangs par spyod pa'i tha ma ni 'phags pa'i ye shes kyis don dam pa'i bden pa rtogs pas na lhag pa shes rab la tha mar dge bar zhes bya /
analyzed: parya ba s'a ne ka ly'a na zhes bya ba tshangs par spyod pa'i tha ma ni 'phags pa'i ye shes kyis don dam pa'i bden pa rtogs pas na lhag pa shes rab la tha mar dge bar zhes bya /
translated: Paripūrṇakalyāṇa means “final in terms of pure conduct.” It is the name for the wisdom of the āryas that realizes ultimate truth. Since it is an action related to superior wisdom, it is called “virtuous in the end.”

original: svartham zhes bya ba su ni bzang po /🔽aartha ni don te don ma log par bstan pas na don bzang po zhes bya /
analyzed: svartham zhes bya ba su ni bzang po / aartha ni don te don ma log par bstan pas na don bzang po zhes bya /
translated: Svartha means “good meaning.”🔽Artha means “meaning.” Since it teaches the meaning without error, it is called “good meaning.”

original: su byanydza na zhes bya ba su ni bzang po /
analyzed: su byanydza na zhes bya ba su ni bzang po /
translated: SubhAnya means “good words.”

original: byanydza na ni tshig 'bru ste /
analyzed: byanydza na ni tshig 'bru ste /
translated: Anya means “words.”

original: tshangs par spyod pa bshad pa'i tshig 'bru go zhing brda phrad par sla ste /
analyzed: tshangs par spyod pa bshad pa'i tshig 'bru go zhing brda phrad par sla ste /
translated: The words that explain pure conduct are easy to understand and communicate.

original: brjod pa phun sum tshogs pa'i phyir tshig 'bru bzang po zhes bya /
analyzed: brjod pa phun sum tshogs pa'i phyir tshig 'bru bzang po zhes bya /
translated: Since it is perfect expression, it is called “good words.”

original: ke ba lam zhes bya ba aa s'a dh'a ra na tv'ad ke ba lam zhes bya ste /
analyzed: ke ba lam zhes bya ba aa s'a dh'a ra na tv'ad ke ba lam zhes bya ste /
translated: The term “kevalam” means “asādhāraṇatva kevalam,” meaning “unshared.”

original: mu stegs can la sogs pa phal dang thun mong ma yin pa'i phyir ma 'dres pa zhes bya /🔽ba ri p'urnnam zhes bya ba sarba kle sha pra ti baksha tv'ad pa ri p'urnnam zhes bya ste /
analyzed: mu stegs can la sogs pa phal dang thun mong ma yin pa'i phyir ma 'dres pa zhes bya / ba ri p'urnnam zhes bya ba sarba kle sha pra ti baksha tv'ad pa ri p'urnnam zhes bya ste /
translated: It is called “unshared” because it is not common to ordinary beings, tīrthikas, and so on.🔽The term “paripūrṇam” means “sarvakleśapratipakṣatva paripūrṇam,” meaning “complete.”

original: srid pa'i rtse mo man chad kyi nyon mongs pa ma lus par rdzogs par spong nus pas na yongs su rdzogs pa zhes bya /🔽ba ri shuddha zhes bya ba sva bh'a ba bi mukty'a bi mukta tv'at pa ri shuddha zhes bya ste /
analyzed: srid pa'i rtse mo man chad kyi nyon mongs pa ma lus par rdzogs par spong nus pas na yongs su rdzogs pa zhes bya / ba ri shuddha zhes bya ba sva bh'a ba bi mukty'a bi mukta tv'at pa ri shuddha zhes bya ste /
translated: It is called “complete” because it is able to completely eliminate all afflictions from the peak of existence down.

original: 'phags pa'i lam zag pa med pa'i rang bzhin gyis rnam par grol te gtsang bas na yongs su dag pa zhes bya /🔽parya ba d'a tam zhes bya ba /
analyzed: 'phags pa'i lam zag pa med pa'i rang bzhin gyis rnam par grol te gtsang bas na yongs su dag pa zhes bya / parya ba d'a tam zhes bya ba /
translated: The term “pariśuddham” means “svabhāvavimuktyā vimuktatvāt pariśuddham,” meaning “pure.”

original: santa na bi mukty'a bi mukta tv'at parya ba d'a tan zhes bya ste /
analyzed: santa na bi mukty'a bi mukta tv'at parya ba d'a tan zhes bya ste /
translated: It is called “pure” because the noble path is pure by nature and is liberated.🔽The term “parivādatam” means “santānavimuktyā vimuktatvāt parivādatam,” meaning “surrounded.”

original: zag pa zad pa rnams kyi sems kyi rgyun la /
analyzed: zag pa zad pa rnams kyi sems kyi rgyun la /
translated: The continuum of the minds of those who have exhausted the contaminants🔽is surrounded by the noble path.

original: 'phags pa'i lam 'byung ste /
analyzed: 'phags pa'i lam 'byung ste /
translated: The noble path arises.

original: gang zag so so'i sems kyi rgyud rnam par grol zhing byang bas na yongs su byang ba zhes bya /
analyzed: gang zag so so'i sems kyi rgyud rnam par grol zhing byang bas na yongs su byang ba zhes bya /
translated: Since the mind-stream of the individual is completely purified and cleansed, it is called “purified.”

original: sv'a khy'a to bha ga ba to dharmma zhes bya ba /
analyzed: sv'a khy'a to bha ga ba to dharmma zhes bya ba /
translated: Svākhyāto bhagavato dharmaḥ

original: aa bi parya ti sa m'a khy'a na sv'a khy'a ta zhes bya ba /
analyzed: aa bi parya ti sa m'a khy'a na sv'a khy'a ta zhes bya ba /
translated: Aviparītasamāhākhyāta iti

original: sangs rgyas kyi chos phyin ci ma log par bstan pas na bcom ldan 'das kyi chos ni legs par gsungs pa zhes bya /
analyzed: sangs rgyas kyi chos phyin ci ma log par bstan pas na bcom ldan 'das kyi chos ni legs par gsungs pa zhes bya /
translated: Since the Buddha’s Dharma is taught without distortion, it is called “well-spoken” by the Bhagavān.🔽Samīkṣakā

original: sam drishti ka zhes bya ba drishta aartha tv'ad sam drishti ka zhes bya ste /
analyzed: sam drishti ka zhes bya ba drishta aartha tv'ad sam drishti ka zhes bya ste /
translated: Dṛṣṭārthatatvamasamīkṣakā

original: dad pa tsam gyis rtogs pa ma yin gyi /
analyzed: dad pa tsam gyis rtogs pa ma yin gyi /
translated: It is not realized merely through faith.

original: yang dag pa'i shes rab kyis yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du ma nor bar mthong bas na yang dag par mthong ba zhes bya /
analyzed: yang dag pa'i shes rab kyis yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du ma nor bar mthong bas na yang dag par mthong ba zhes bya /
translated: Since it is seen correctly and without error just as it is through right wisdom, it is called “correctly seen.”

original: nirdzvar zhes bya ba /
analyzed: nirdzvar zhes bya ba /
translated: Nirjava

original: kle sha aa nu sha ya bra ti bhaksha tv'ad nirdzva ra zhes bya ste /
analyzed: kle sha aa nu sha ya bra ti bhaksha tv'ad nirdzva ra zhes bya ste /
translated: Kleśānuśayapratibhakṣatvad nirjava

original: nyon mongs pa bag la nyal gyi gnyen po yin pas nyon mongs pa dang / nye ba'i nyon mongs pa'i rims nad bsal zhing yongs su nyams par mi 'gyur bas na nad med pa zhes bya /🔽aa k'a li ka zhes bya ba rnam pa gcig @144a * //
analyzed: nyon mongs pa bag la nyal gyi gnyen po yin pas nyon mongs pa dang / nye ba'i nyon mongs pa'i rims nad bsal zhing yongs su nyams par mi 'gyur bas na nad med pa zhes bya / aa k'a li ka zhes bya ba rnam pa gcig @144a * //
translated: Since it is the antidote to the latent afflictions, it is called “the absence of afflictions” and “the absence of secondary afflictions.” Since it eliminates the disease of the afflictions and secondary afflictions, it is called “the absence of disease.”🔽Akālika means “not untimely.”

original: tu na k'a la ni ya m'a bh'a b'ad aa k'a li k'a zhes bya ste /
analyzed: tu na k'a la ni ya m'a bh'a b'ad aa k'a li k'a zhes bya ste /
translated: In one sense, it means kāla-naiva-bhāvad-akālika.

original: skabs gang du yang sgom du rung ste /
analyzed: skabs gang du yang sgom du rung ste /
translated: It is suitable to meditate at any time,

original: dus nges pa med pa'i phyir dus chad pa med pa zhes bya /
analyzed: dus nges pa med pa'i phyir dus chad pa med pa zhes bya /
translated: so it is called “not untimely” because there is no fixed time.

original: yang rnam pa gcig tu na sarba k'a la su kha tsa tv'a ra aa k'a li k'a zhes bya ste /
analyzed: yang rnam pa gcig tu na sarba k'a la su kha tsa tv'a ra aa k'a li k'a zhes bya ste /
translated: In another sense, it means sarva-kāla-sukha-caturthā-varā-akālika.

original: spyod lam bzhi po'i dus kun tu bya bar sla bas dus chad pa med pa zhes bya /
analyzed: spyod lam bzhi po'i dus kun tu bya bar sla bas dus chad pa med pa zhes bya /
translated: It is easy to practice at all times, in the four modes of conduct, so it is called “not untimely.”

original: aoo pa na yi k'a zhes bya ba aa she sha du:kha niry'a na au pa na ya n'ad aoo pa na yi k'a zhes bya ste /
analyzed: aoo pa na yi k'a zhes bya ba aa she sha du:kha niry'a na au pa na ya n'ad aoo pa na yi k'a zhes bya ste /
translated: Aupa-na-yika means aśeṣa-duḥkha-nirvāṇa-upa-nayanād-aupa-na-yika.

original: sdug bsngal ma lus pa las 'byung ba nye bar spyod pa'i phyir nye bar gtod pa zhes bya /🔽aee hi ba shyi ka zhes bya ba aa s'a dh'a ra na tv'ad aee ha ba shyi ka ai ha pa shyeshta bha ba zhes bya ste /
analyzed: sdug bsngal ma lus pa las 'byung ba nye bar spyod pa'i phyir nye bar gtod pa zhes bya / aee hi ba shyi ka zhes bya ba aa s'a dh'a ra na tv'ad aee ha ba shyi ka ai ha pa shyeshta bha ba zhes bya ste /
translated: It is called the foundation because it is the foundation for the experience of the emergence of all suffering.

original: chos 'di mthong ba rnams la yod pas mu stegs can dang thun mong ma yin pa'i phyir 'di mthong ba la yod pa zhes bya /
analyzed: chos 'di mthong ba rnams la yod pas mu stegs can dang thun mong ma yin pa'i phyir 'di mthong ba la yod pa zhes bya /
translated: Aihivasika means that since it exists for those who see this Dharma, it is called that which exists for those who see this, because it is not common to tīrthikas.

original: yang rnam pa gcig tu na /🔽a'a ts'arya mushti ra hi ta tv'ad ai ha pa shya ti pra b'a ra na yo g'ad ces bya ste /
analyzed: yang rnam pa gcig tu na / a'a ts'arya mushti ra hi ta tv'ad ai ha pa shya ti pra b'a ra na yo g'ad ces bya ste /
translated: Or, in another way,🔽it is called that which exists for those who see this because it is said, “O ācārya, open your fist and look at this.”

original: slob dpon 'chab pa med pas 'di la ltos shig ces skabs 'byed pa dang ldan pa'i phyir 'di ltos ldan zhes kyang bya ste /
analyzed: slob dpon 'chab pa med pas 'di la ltos shig ces skabs 'byed pa dang ldan pa'i phyir 'di ltos ldan zhes kyang bya ste /
translated: Since the master is without concealment, it is said, “Open your fist and look at this,” because it is endowed with the opportunity to do so.

original: tshig rnam pa gnyis su drang du rung gis kyang don sngon ma dang sbyar te bshad na bzang zhing tshig kyang bde ste /
analyzed: tshig rnam pa gnyis su drang du rung gis kyang don sngon ma dang sbyar te bshad na bzang zhing tshig kyang bde ste /
translated: Although it is suitable to interpret the words in two ways, if it is explained in conjunction with the former meaning, it is good and the words are easy to understand.

original: 'di mthong ba la yod pa zhes btags /
analyzed: 'di mthong ba la yod pa zhes btags /
translated: It is called that which exists for those who see this.

original: pra ty'atma be da n'i yo bidznya zhes bya ba aa tarkya tv'ad pra ty'atma be da bi dznyee zhes bya ste /
analyzed: pra ty'atma be da n'i yo bidznya zhes bya ba aa tarkya tv'ad pra ty'atma be da bi dznyee zhes bya ste /
translated: Pratyātmavedanīyo’vijñeyaḥ means that which is to be realized by oneself and not by others.

original: rnam pa gcig tu na rtog ge'i yul ma yin te /
analyzed: rnam pa gcig tu na rtog ge'i yul ma yin te /
translated: In one sense, it is not the object of logic.

original: shes rab can rnams kyis rtogs par bya ba yin pa dang / yang rnam pa gcig tu na aa na bhi la pya tv'ad pr'a ty'atma be da n'i ya zhes bya ste /
analyzed: shes rab can rnams kyis rtogs par bya ba yin pa dang / yang rnam pa gcig tu na aa na bhi la pya tv'ad pr'a ty'atma be da n'i ya zhes bya ste /
translated: It is to be realized by the wise, and in another sense, it is said to be anabhilāpyātmapratyātmavedanīya.

original: brjod du med pa'i phyir so sor rang gi rig par zad pas mkhas pa rnams kyis rig par bya ba zhes bya /🔽sv'a khy'a to bha ga ba to dharmma bi na ya su pra be di na ta zhes pa n+y'a ya tv'ad aa bi pa r'i tartha tve na dharmma kle sha bi na ya zhes bya ste /
analyzed: brjod du med pa'i phyir so sor rang gi rig par zad pas mkhas pa rnams kyis rig par bya ba zhes bya / sv'a khy'a to bha ga ba to dharmma bi na ya su pra be di na ta zhes pa n+y'a ya tv'ad aa bi pa r'i tartha tve na dharmma kle sha bi na ya zhes bya ste /
translated: Since it is inexpressible, it is to be realized by oneself alone. Therefore, it is said to be that which is to be realized by the wise.🔽Svākhyāto bhagavato dharmavinayo suvibhakto nidarśito’viparītaḥ kleśavyapadam iti.

original: bcom ldan 'das kyis legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba gzhan phyi rol pa dang mi 'dra bar legs par bstan cing go bar byas te /
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das kyis legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba gzhan phyi rol pa dang mi 'dra bar legs par bstan cing go bar byas te /
translated: The well-spoken Dharma and Vinaya of the Blessed One is well-taught and understood, not like the externalist teachings.

original: rigs pa dang ldan pas na chos /
analyzed: rigs pa dang ldan pas na chos /
translated: Since it is reasonable, it is the Dharma.

original: nyon mongs pa zhi zhing dul bar byed pas na 'dul ba ste tshig bsdus na bcom ldan 'das kyis legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba legs par bstan pa zhes bya /🔽neery'a ni ka sam bo dhi g'a m'i zhes bya ba /
analyzed: nyon mongs pa zhi zhing dul bar byed pas na 'dul ba ste tshig bsdus na bcom ldan 'das kyis legs par gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba legs par bstan pa zhes bya / neery'a ni ka sam bo dhi g'a m'i zhes bya ba /
translated: The concise form is “the well-taught discipline of the doctrine well spoken by the Bhagavat.”🔽Nirvāṇagāmi

original: sam bo dhi g'a m'i tve na neery'a ni ka zhes bya ba ste /
analyzed: sam bo dhi g'a m'i tve na neery'a ni ka zhes bya ba ste /
translated: Nirvāṇagāmi means “going to nirvāṇa.”

original: tshig 'di gnyis ni 'og mas @144b gong ma bshad pa yin te /
analyzed: tshig 'di gnyis ni 'og mas @144b gong ma bshad pa yin te /
translated: These two words explain the preceding one.

original: rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu 'gro bar byed pas mya ngan las 'das par nges par 'byung ba'i phyir nges par 'byung ba rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu 'gro bar byed pa zhes bya /
analyzed: rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu 'gro bar byed pas mya ngan las 'das par nges par 'byung ba'i phyir nges par 'byung ba rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu 'gro bar byed pa zhes bya /
translated: It is a going to complete enlightenment because it is a going to nirvāṇa.🔽Abhinnasatva

original: aa bhinna sa st'u ba zhes bya ba ni bcom ldan 'das kyi gsung rab la nyan thos rnams lta ba mi mthun pa med de /
analyzed: aa bhinna sa st'u ba zhes bya ba ni bcom ldan 'das kyi gsung rab la nyan thos rnams lta ba mi mthun pa med de /
translated: The Bhagavat’s scriptures are not of different views for the śrāvakas.

original: gcig tu 'dus pas na mi mthun pa med cing 'dus pa dang ldan pa zhes bya /
analyzed: gcig tu 'dus pas na mi mthun pa med cing 'dus pa dang ldan pa zhes bya /
translated: They are of one accord, and therefore they are said to be “without difference and endowed with an assembly.”

original: sa pra ti shar na zhes bya ba sa ni bcas pa 'am yod pa la bya /
analyzed: sa pra ti shar na zhes bya ba sa ni bcas pa 'am yod pa la bya /
translated: Sapratisharaṇa means that sa means “to be established” or “to exist.”

original: pra ti sha ra na ni skyabs sam dpung gnyen nam rten du rung ba la bya ste /
analyzed: pra ti sha ra na ni skyabs sam dpung gnyen nam rten du rung ba la bya ste /
translated: Pratisharaṇa means “to be a refuge,” “to be a protector,” or “to be a support.”

original: mu stegs can gyi chos lta bu khungs ngan par 'byin pa ma yin gyi /
analyzed: mu stegs can gyi chos lta bu khungs ngan par 'byin pa ma yin gyi /
translated: It is not like the non-Buddhist teachings, which are based on bad sources.

original: de bzhin gshegs pas gsungs pa yin pas na rten pa yod pa zhes bya /
analyzed: de bzhin gshegs pas gsungs pa yin pas na rten pa yod pa zhes bya /
translated: Since it was taught by the Tathāgata, it is called “that which has an established basis.”

original: tshindha plo ti ka zhes bya ba tshindha ni chad pa /🔽plo ti ka ni plum ga too zhes bya ste /
analyzed: tshindha plo ti ka zhes bya ba tshindha ni chad pa / plo ti ka ni plum ga too zhes bya ste /
translated: Tshin dha blo ti ka means that tshin dha is “to be cut off.”

original: 'gro ba 'am chus ded cing khyer ba lta bu'i tshig yin /
analyzed: 'gro ba 'am chus ded cing khyer ba lta bu'i tshig yin /
translated: Blo ti ka is “to be carried away” or “to be swept away.”

original: spyir na 'khor bar skye zhing 'pho ba'i rgyu rgyu ba bcad pa la bya ste rgyu ba bcad pa zhes bya /
analyzed: spyir na 'khor bar skye zhing 'pho ba'i rgyu rgyu ba bcad pa la bya ste rgyu ba bcad pa zhes bya /
translated: In general, it means to cut off the cause of being born and transmigrating in saṃsāra.

original: 'jig rten pa'i lha'i ming la brahma zhes bya ba /🔽bri had ku sha la m'u la nirdzata tad brahma zhes bya ste /
analyzed: 'jig rten pa'i lha'i ming la brahma zhes bya ba / bri had ku sha la m'u la nirdzata tad brahma zhes bya ste /
translated: The name of a worldly god is called brahma.

original: dge ba'i rtsa ba chen po las skyes pas chen po par yang drang du rung /
analyzed: dge ba'i rtsa ba chen po las skyes pas chen po par yang drang du rung /
translated: Bṛhatkuśalamūla-nirjāta-tad-brahma means that since it is born from a great root of virtue, it is also suitable to be called “great.”

original: yang rnam pa gcig tu na mu stegs can gyi gzhung las tshangs pa ni bden pa'o //
analyzed: yang rnam pa gcig tu na mu stegs can gyi gzhung las tshangs pa ni bden pa'o //
translated: Again, in one sense, it is said in the tīrthika scriptures, “Brahmā is truth.

original: tshangs pa ni dka' thub po /
analyzed: tshangs pa ni dka' thub po /
translated: Brahmā is austerity.🔽Brahmā is the one who conquers the senses.”

original: tshangs pa ni dbang po thub pa'o zhes 'byung by'a ka ra na las ni bri ha n'ad brahma zhes bya ste /
analyzed: tshangs pa ni dbang po thub pa'o zhes 'byung by'a ka ra na las ni bri ha n'ad brahma zhes bya ste /
translated: From the Vyakaraṇa it is said, “Brahmā is the one who expands.”

original: tshe dang byad gzugs dang gnas dang longs spyod la sogs pa 'og ma bas 'phel zhing khyad par du gyur pas 'phel ba 'am rgyas pa zhes drang du yang rung /
analyzed: tshe dang byad gzugs dang gnas dang longs spyod la sogs pa 'og ma bas 'phel zhing khyad par du gyur pas 'phel ba 'am rgyas pa zhes drang du yang rung /
translated: Since lifespan, body, place, resources, and so on are increased and become special compared to lower levels, it is suitable to translate it as “expansion” or “increase.”

original: yang rnam pa gcig tu na by'a khy'a yukti las brahma bh'u ta shi ta bh'u ta zhes 'byung ste //
analyzed: yang rnam pa gcig tu na by'a khy'a yukti las brahma bh'u ta shi ta bh'u ta zhes 'byung ste //
translated: Again, in one sense, from the Vyakhyāyukti it is said, “Brahmā is the one who is born cool.”

original: 'dod khams kyi nyon mongs pa'i tsha ba dang bral nas bsam gtan dang po'i sar phyin pas nyon mongs pa 'og ma las thar zhing bsil bar gyur pa yin te /
analyzed: 'dod khams kyi nyon mongs pa'i tsha ba dang bral nas bsam gtan dang po'i sar phyin pas nyon mongs pa 'og ma las thar zhing bsil bar gyur pa yin te /
translated: Since he is free from the heat of affliction of the desire realm and has gone to the first level of absorption, he is free from lower affliction and has become cool.

original: rnam pa 'di snyed du drang du rung gis kyang don dang yang sbyar /
analyzed: rnam pa 'di snyed du drang du rung gis kyang don dang yang sbyar /
translated: It is suitable to translate it in these many ways, but it should also be applied to the meaning.

original: sngar grags pa yang btsan par byas nas tshangs pa zhes btags bishnu zhes bya ba rnam pa gcig tu na bi shlo by'aptoo zhes bya ste khyab par yang 'dren /
analyzed: sngar grags pa yang btsan par byas nas tshangs pa zhes btags bishnu zhes bya ba rnam pa gcig tu na bi shlo by'aptoo zhes bya ste khyab par yang 'dren /
translated: He was also known as Brahma, and Vishnu. In one way, Vishnu is called Vishva-vyapti, which means “pervading.”

original: yang rnam pa gcig tu na bi sha phra be sha zhes bya ste kun du 'jug pa la yang bya /
analyzed: yang rnam pa gcig tu na bi sha phra be sha zhes bya ste kun du 'jug pa la yang bya /
translated: In another way, Vishnu is called Vishva-vibhu, which means “all-pervading.”

original: spyir na 'jig rten yod do cog kyang bishnu'i rang bzhin yin te /
analyzed: spyir na 'jig rten yod do cog kyang bishnu'i rang bzhin yin te /
translated: In general, all existing worlds are of the nature of Vishnu.

original: kun la khyab bar 'jug pas na khyab 'jug ces bya /🔽ma he shva ra @145a * //
analyzed: kun la khyab bar 'jug pas na khyab 'jug ces bya / ma he shva ra @145a * //
translated: Because he pervades and enters all, he is called Vishnu.🔽Mahesvara

original: zhes bya ba ma h'a ni chen po a'i shva ra ni a'i sha aee shvarya zhes bya ste /
analyzed: zhes bya ba ma h'a ni chen po a'i shva ra ni a'i sha aee shvarya zhes bya ste /
translated: Mahesvara is mahat, which means “great,” and isvara, which means “lord.”

original: spyir na dbang che zhing phyug btsan pa la bya /
analyzed: spyir na dbang che zhing phyug btsan pa la bya /
translated: In general, it means “great lord” and “powerful.”

original: dngos su na mu stegs can gyi lta gu lang yin te dbang phyug chen po zhes bya /
analyzed: dngos su na mu stegs can gyi lta gu lang yin te dbang phyug chen po zhes bya /
translated: In particular, it is the view of the tirthikas that Shiva is the great lord.🔽Mara

original: m'a ra zhes bya ba mring pr'a na tya ge zhes bya ste /
analyzed: m'a ra zhes bya ba mring pr'a na tya ge zhes bya ste /
translated: Mara is mrityu-pramatha-gata, which means

original: dge ba'i chos kyi srog dang bral bar byed pas na bdud ces bya /
analyzed: dge ba'i chos kyi srog dang bral bar byed pas na bdud ces bya /
translated: “one who deprives one of the life force of virtuous qualities.” Therefore, he is called Mara, the Evil One.

original: shakra zhes bya ba /
analyzed: shakra zhes bya ba /
translated: Śakra means

original: shakli  shaktoo shakto de ba r'a dz'a r'a ga pra tyan zhes bya ste /
analyzed: shakli  shaktoo shakto de ba r'a dz'a r'a ga pra tyan zhes bya ste /
translated: śakli śakto’śakto devā rājā rāga pratyan.

original: lha'i srid thub cing lha ma yin las rgyal bar nus pas na /
analyzed: lha'i srid thub cing lha ma yin las rgyal bar nus pas na /
translated: Since he is able to conquer the gods and is able to conquer the demigods,

original: srid thub cing nus pa la yang bya /
analyzed: srid thub cing nus pa la yang bya /
translated: he is called “able to conquer” and “able to do.”

original: yang rnam pa gcig tu na /
analyzed: yang rnam pa gcig tu na /
translated: Moreover, in one aspect,

original: mchod sbyin rnam pa brgya byas pas lha'i rgyal po'i go 'phang thob pas na brgya byin zhes kyang bya /
analyzed: mchod sbyin rnam pa brgya byas pas lha'i rgyal po'i go 'phang thob pas na brgya byin zhes kyang bya /
translated: since he performed a hundred types of sacrifices, he obtained the state of king of the gods, so he is called Śatakratu.

original: tshig 'di gnyis ka yang drang du rung mod kyi /🔽sngar ming du btags pa btsan par byas te brgya byin zhes btags /
analyzed: tshig 'di gnyis ka yang drang du rung mod kyi / sngar ming du btags pa btsan par byas te brgya byin zhes btags /
translated: Both of these terms are suitable to be applied to him.

original: aindra zhes bya ba /
analyzed: aindra zhes bya ba /
translated: However, since the name given earlier is more powerful, he is called Śatakratu.🔽Indra means

original: ai di pa ra me shvarya zhes bya ba ste /
analyzed: ai di pa ra me shvarya zhes bya ba ste /
translated: īḍa parameśvara.

original: ri rab kyi steng na sum cu rtsa gsum pa'i lha'i rgyal po mdzad pas na brgya byin gyi ming gi rnam grangs te dbang po zhes bya /
analyzed: ri rab kyi steng na sum cu rtsa gsum pa'i lha'i rgyal po mdzad pas na brgya byin gyi ming gi rnam grangs te dbang po zhes bya /
translated: Since he acts as the king of the gods of the Thirty-Three on top of Mount Meru, he is called Śakra, a synonym for Indra, and is called “lord.”

original: lo ka p'a la zhes bya ba lo ka ni lu dzya ti ai ti lo ka zhes bya ste /
analyzed: lo ka p'a la zhes bya ba lo ka ni lu dzya ti ai ti lo ka zhes bya ste /
translated: Lo kapāla means loka means lujya iti loka.

original: 'jig rten p'a la raksha na zhes bya ste /
analyzed: 'jig rten p'a la raksha na zhes bya ste /
translated: In the world, he is called Lokapala,

original: 'jig rten srung zhing skyong ba zhes bya /
analyzed: 'jig rten srung zhing skyong ba zhes bya /
translated: which means “protector and guardian of the world.”

original: bee shra ba na zhes bya ba ni bi shra ba na sya a'a pattya bee shra ma na zhes bya ste /
analyzed: bee shra ba na zhes bya ba ni bi shra ba na sya a'a pattya bee shra ma na zhes bya ste /
translated: Visravana means “having come from Visrava,”

original: rnam thos kyi bu zhes bya'o //
analyzed: rnam thos kyi bu zhes bya'o //
translated: which is the name of his father.

original: dhri ta r'ashta zhes bya ba ni /🔽dhri ta ni srung ba 'am 'dzin pa /
analyzed: dhri ta r'ashta zhes bya ba ni / dhri ta ni srung ba 'am 'dzin pa /
translated: Dhritarashtra means

original: r'ashta ni yul 'khor te yul 'khor srung zhes bya /
analyzed: r'ashta ni yul 'khor te yul 'khor srung zhes bya /
translated: “holding the land” or “protecting the land.”

original: bi ru dh'a  ka zhes bya ba bi ni bi she sha na ste /
analyzed: bi ru dh'a  ka zhes bya ba bi ni bi she sha na ste /
translated: Virudhaka means “having a special birth,”

original: bye brag tu gyur pa 'am 'phags pa la bya /
analyzed: bye brag tu gyur pa 'am 'phags pa la bya /
translated: which refers to a noble being.🔽Rudha means “birth,”

original: ru dha ni ru ha dzanma ni zhes bya ste skyes pa la bya /
analyzed: ru dha ni ru ha dzanma ni zhes bya ste skyes pa la bya /
translated: and Rudhajanma means “having a birth.”

original: ka ni sam bi dzny'a y'a na ka na zhes bya ba /
analyzed: ka ni sam bi dzny'a y'a na ka na zhes bya ba /
translated: Kan means “to know,”🔽and sam means “together.”

original: ming gcig gi mjug la by'a ka ra na'i gzhung gis kas gdags pa yod pas tshig gi rkyen du btags par zad de /🔽'phags skyes po zhes bya /
analyzed: ming gcig gi mjug la by'a ka ra na'i gzhung gis kas gdags pa yod pas tshig gi rkyen du btags par zad de /🔽'phags skyes po zhes bya /
translated: Virudhaka is the name of a king of the gandharvas.

original: bi r'u p'akshi zhes bya ba rnam pa gcig tu na bi r'u pa zhes pa ni spyan gzhan dang mi 'dra ba gsum mnga' bas mi mthun pa la bya /
analyzed: bi r'u p'akshi zhes bya ba rnam pa gcig tu na bi r'u pa zhes pa ni spyan gzhan dang mi 'dra ba gsum mnga' bas mi mthun pa la bya /
translated: Virūpākṣa. In one way, virūpa means “unlike others,” and akṣa means “eye.”

original: aakshi zhes bya ba ni mig la bya ste mig mi 'dra ba 'am /🔽rnam pa gcig tu na bi r'u pa ni klu'i rgyal po yin pas na spyan la gdug pa mnga' ste gzigs so 'tshal la gnod par 'gyur bas mig mi bzang zhes bya /
analyzed: aakshi zhes bya ba ni mig la bya ste mig mi 'dra ba 'am / rnam pa gcig tu na bi r'u pa ni klu'i rgyal po yin pas na spyan la gdug pa mnga' ste gzigs so 'tshal la gnod par 'gyur bas mig mi bzang zhes bya /
translated: Thus, it means “unlike eyes.”🔽In another way, virūpa means “the king of nāgas,” and akṣa means “to see.”

original: // / bam po gnyis pa /
analyzed: // / bam po gnyis pa /
translated: Thus, it means “unpleasant eyes,” because the eyes are harmful to look at.

original: pha rol tu phyin pa bcu dang / byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos sum cu rtsa bdun la sogs @145b pa'i ming la /
analyzed: pha rol tu phyin pa bcu dang / byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos sum cu rtsa bdun la sogs @145b pa'i ming la /
translated: The ten perfections and the thirty-seven factors of awakening, and so on🔽The ten perfections

original: pha rol tu phyin pa bcu dang / da sha pa ra mi t'a zhes bya ba /
analyzed: pha rol tu phyin pa bcu dang / da sha pa ra mi t'a zhes bya ba /
translated: daśa-pāramitā

original: da sha ni bcu /
analyzed: da sha ni bcu /
translated: daśa means “ten.”

original: pa ra mi t'a ni pa ra ai ta pa ra mi t'a zhes bya ste /
analyzed: pa ra mi t'a ni pa ra ai ta pa ra mi t'a zhes bya ste /
translated: pāramitā is param-īta-pāramite, meaning “gone to the other side.”

original: sbyin pa dang / tshul khrims dang / bzod pa dang / brtson 'grus dang / bsam gtan dang / shes rab dang / thabs dang / smon lam dang / stobs dang / ye shes dang ; 'di bcu la spyad cing bsgom pa'i mthar phyin te /
analyzed: sbyin pa dang / tshul khrims dang / bzod pa dang / brtson 'grus dang / bsam gtan dang / shes rab dang / thabs dang / smon lam dang / stobs dang / ye shes dang ; 'di bcu la spyad cing bsgom pa'i mthar phyin te /
translated: Generosity, moral discipline, patience, perseverance, meditative concentration, wisdom, skillful means, aspiration, strength, and gnosis.

original: phyi na ma lus pas na pha rol tu phyin pa bcu zhes bya /
analyzed: phyi na ma lus pas na pha rol tu phyin pa bcu zhes bya /
translated: Since one has practiced and meditated on these ten and brought them to completion, without leaving anything outside, they are called the ten perfections.

original: byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos sum cu rtsa bdun la sogs pa'i ming la sapta trim shadbo dhi paksha zhes bya ba bodhi ra nu gu ru na tv'adbo dhi paksha zhes bya ste /
analyzed: byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos sum cu rtsa bdun la sogs pa'i ming la sapta trim shadbo dhi paksha zhes bya ba bodhi ra nu gu ru na tv'adbo dhi paksha zhes bya ste /
translated: The names of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment and so forth are as follows: sapta-triṃśad-bodhi-pakṣāḥ. Bodhi-rūpa-guru-nata-tva-bodhi-pakṣāḥ.

original: bodhi ni byang chub /
analyzed: bodhi ni byang chub /
translated: Bodhi means enlightenment.

original: paksha ni de'i rjes su mthun pa'am phyogs su gyur pa la bya ste /
analyzed: paksha ni de'i rjes su mthun pa'am phyogs su gyur pa la bya ste /
translated: Pakṣa means that which is in accord with it or that which is on its side.

original: dran pa nye bar gzhag pa nas 'phags pa'i lam yan lag brgyad pa'i bar du sum cu rtsa bdun yod pa 'di byang chub gsum po'i phyogs su gyur pas na byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos sum cu rtsa bdun zhes bya ba /🔽tsa tv'a ri smri tyu pasth'a na zhes bya ba pra dzny'a ya smri ti r'u pa tishtha te zhes bya ste /
analyzed: dran pa nye bar gzhag pa nas 'phags pa'i lam yan lag brgyad pa'i bar du sum cu rtsa bdun yod pa 'di byang chub gsum po'i phyogs su gyur pas na byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos sum cu rtsa bdun zhes bya ba / tsa tv'a ri smri tyu pasth'a na zhes bya ba pra dzny'a ya smri ti r'u pa tishtha te zhes bya ste /
translated: The Sanskrit catur is four, smṛtyupasthāna is application of mindfulness, and āryāṣṭāṅga is noble eightfold.

original: smri ti dran pa /🔽au pa ni nye ba /
analyzed: smri ti dran pa / au pa ni nye ba /
translated: Smṛti is mindfulness,🔽upasthāna is application,

original: sth'a na ni gzhag pa la bya /
analyzed: sth'a na ni gzhag pa la bya /
translated: and āṅga is branch.

original: spyir na lus dang sems dang tshor ba dang chos bzhi'i rang dang spyi'i mtshan nyid shes rab kyis brtags ti mthong ba rnams dran pas gsal bar 'dzin te /
analyzed: spyir na lus dang sems dang tshor ba dang chos bzhi'i rang dang spyi'i mtshan nyid shes rab kyis brtags ti mthong ba rnams dran pas gsal bar 'dzin te /
translated: In general, the four applications of mindfulness are so called because they are the application of mindfulness to the clear retention by means of mindfulness of the body, mind, feelings, and phenomena, which are investigated by means of the wisdom that sees the general and specific characteristics of these four.

original: dran pa shas che bas dran pa nye bar gzhag pa bzhi zhes bya /🔽tsa tv'a ri samyakpra ha na zhes bya ba /🔽tsa tv'a ri ni bzhi /🔽samyaka ni yang dag pa /
analyzed: dran pa shas che bas dran pa nye bar gzhag pa bzhi zhes bya / tsa tv'a ri samyakpra ha na zhes bya ba / tsa tv'a ri ni bzhi / samyaka ni yang dag pa /
translated: Since mindfulness is predominant, they are called the four applications of mindfulness.

original: pra ha na ni spong ba ste /
analyzed: pra ha na ni spong ba ste /
translated: The Sanskrit samyak is correct, and prahāṇa is abandonment.

original: brtson 'grus kyis dge ba skyed cing sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos rnams spong bas na yang dag par spong ba bzhi zhes bya /
analyzed: brtson 'grus kyis dge ba skyed cing sdig pa mi dge ba'i chos rnams spong bas na yang dag par spong ba bzhi zhes bya /
translated: Since one generates virtue and abandons nonvirtue through diligence, it is called the four perfect abandonments.

original: tsa tv'a ri ri dhi p'a da zhes bya ba ri dhi ni rdzu 'phrul p'a da ni rkang pa ste 'dun pa dang sems dang brtson 'grus dang dpyod pa'i ting nge 'dzin bzhi nam mkha' la 'gro ba la sogs pa'i rdzu 'phrul gyi rten dang rgyur gyur pas
analyzed: tsa tv'a ri ri dhi p'a da zhes bya ba ri dhi ni rdzu 'phrul p'a da ni rkang pa ste 'dun pa dang sems dang brtson 'grus dang dpyod pa'i ting nge 'dzin bzhi nam mkha' la 'gro ba la sogs pa'i rdzu 'phrul gyi rten dang rgyur gyur pas
translated: CATVARĪ ṚDDHIPĀDĀNI means ṛddhi is miracle power, pāda is foot. The four concentrations of aspiration, mind, diligence, and analysis are the basis and cause of miracle powers such as flying through the sky.

original: na rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bzhi zhes bya /
analyzed: na rdzu 'phrul gyi rkang pa bzhi zhes bya /
translated: Therefore they are called the four feet of miracle power.

original: panytsendri ya ni zhes bya ba panytsa ni lnga /
analyzed: panytsendri ya ni zhes bya ba panytsa ni lnga /
translated: PAÑCA INDRIYĀNI means five.

original: aindri ya ni ai di pa ra me shvarya zhes bya ba dbang che ba la bya bas dad pa dang / brtson 'grus dang / dran pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / shes rab dang 'di lnga'i dbang gis sems las su rung ba'i rgyud la thar pa'i cha dang mthun pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba skye bas na /🔽dge ba'i rtsa ba skye ba la dbang ba'i phyir dbang po lnga zhes bya /
analyzed: aindri ya ni ai di pa ra me shvarya zhes bya ba dbang che ba la bya bas dad pa dang / brtson 'grus dang / dran pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / shes rab dang 'di lnga'i dbang gis sems las su rung ba'i rgyud la thar pa'i cha dang mthun pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba skye bas na / dge ba'i rtsa ba skye ba la dbang ba'i phyir dbang po lnga zhes bya /
translated: Faith, diligence, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom are called the five faculties because the roots of virtue that are conducive to liberation arise in a mind that is flexible due to the power of these five.

original: panytsa ba la zhes bya ba panytsa ni lnga /
analyzed: panytsa ba la zhes bya ba panytsa ni lnga /
translated: Because they are powerful in the sense of being lords with regard to the arising of the roots of virtue, they are called the five faculties.

original: ba la ni stobs te /🔽dad pa la @146a * //🔽sogs pa lnga po 'di nyid rgyun ring du bsgoms pas /
analyzed: ba la ni stobs te / dad pa la @146a * // sogs pa lnga po 'di nyid rgyun ring du bsgoms pas /
translated: Bala means “strength.”🔽These five, faith and so on, are called the five strengths because they are powerful in the sense of being able to overcome the five nonvirtues.

original: ma dad pa dang / le lo dang / dran pa nyams pa dang / g-yeng ba dang / shes bzhin ma yin pa dang / mi mthun pa'i phyogs lnga po 'dis bar chad bya mi nus pas na dad pa la sogs pa'i mthu skyes pa'i phyir stobs lnga zhes bya /
analyzed: ma dad pa dang / le lo dang / dran pa nyams pa dang / g-yeng ba dang / shes bzhin ma yin pa dang / mi mthun pa'i phyogs lnga po 'dis bar chad bya mi nus pas na dad pa la sogs pa'i mthu skyes pa'i phyir stobs lnga zhes bya /
translated: These five, faith and so on, are called the five strengths because they are powerful in the sense of being able to overcome the five nonvirtues.

original: sapta bo dhyam ga zhes bya ba sapta ni bdun /
analyzed: sapta bo dhyam ga zhes bya ba sapta ni bdun /
translated: Sapta-bodhyanga means seven.

original: bo dhi ni byang chub /
analyzed: bo dhi ni byang chub /
translated: Bodhi means enlightenment.

original: aam ga ni yan lag ste /🔽dran pa dang / chos rnam par 'byed pa dang / brtson 'grus dang / dga' ba dang / shin tu sbyangs pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / btang snyoms dang / 'di bdun mthong ba'i lam la de kho na nyid byang chub pa'i rgyur gyur pas na /
analyzed: aam ga ni yan lag ste / dran pa dang / chos rnam par 'byed pa dang / brtson 'grus dang / dga' ba dang / shin tu sbyangs pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / btang snyoms dang / 'di bdun mthong ba'i lam la de kho na nyid byang chub pa'i rgyur gyur pas na /
translated: Aṅga means branch.

original: byang chub kyi yan lag bdun zhes bya /
analyzed: byang chub kyi yan lag bdun zhes bya /
translated: These seven—recollection, discernment of phenomena, diligence, joy, pliancy, concentration, and equanimity—are the branches of enlightenment because they are the causes of enlightenment, of realizing suchness, on the path of seeing.

original: yang rnam pa gcig tu na bi bh'a sha las 'byung ba ming du bgrangs pa'i grangs kyis rim pa bzhin bshad pa tsam du zad de /🔽byang chub gsum du 'grub pa'i nye ba'i rgyu de bdun yin pas sgom pa'i lam la byang chub kyi yan lag ces bshad /
analyzed: yang rnam pa gcig tu na bi bh'a sha las 'byung ba ming du bgrangs pa'i grangs kyis rim pa bzhin bshad pa tsam du zad de / byang chub gsum du 'grub pa'i nye ba'i rgyu de bdun yin pas sgom pa'i lam la byang chub kyi yan lag ces bshad /
translated: Alternatively, the order in the Vyākhyāyukti is merely an explanation of the order of the enumeration of the names.

original: a'ary'asht'am ga m'argga zhes bya ba a'arya ni 'phags pa /🔽aasht'am ga ni yan lag brgyad /
analyzed: a'ary'asht'am ga m'argga zhes bya ba a'arya ni 'phags pa / aasht'am ga ni yan lag brgyad /
translated: Since these seven are the proximate causes for accomplishing the three enlightenments, they are explained as the branches of enlightenment on the path of meditation.

original: m'argga ni lam ste /
analyzed: m'argga ni lam ste /
translated: Ārya-aṣṭāṅga-mārga means noble, eight, and path.

original: yang dag pa'i lta ba dang / rtog pa dang / ngag dang / las kyi mtha' dang / 'tsho ba dang / rtsol ba dang / dran pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / 'phags pa'i sgom pa'i lam 'di brgyad ni dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu thob pas na 'phags pa'i lam yan lag brgyad pa zhes bya /
analyzed: yang dag pa'i lta ba dang / rtog pa dang / ngag dang / las kyi mtha' dang / 'tsho ba dang / rtsol ba dang / dran pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / 'phags pa'i sgom pa'i lam 'di brgyad ni dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu thob pas na 'phags pa'i lam yan lag brgyad pa zhes bya /
translated: The eightfold noble path of right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration are called the eightfold noble path because they are the path to attaining the result of arhatship.

original: yang rnam pa gcig tu na bi bh'a sha las 'byung ba 'phags pa'i 'bras bu dang de kho na nyid sngon ma mthong ba mthong bar bya ba'i lam yin pas na mthong ba'i lam du bshad /
analyzed: yang rnam pa gcig tu na bi bh'a sha las 'byung ba 'phags pa'i 'bras bu dang de kho na nyid sngon ma mthong ba mthong bar bya ba'i lam yin pas na mthong ba'i lam du bshad /
translated: Alternatively, the Abhidharmakośa states that it is called the path of seeing because it is the path on which one sees the noble result and reality that one has not seen before.

original: tshad med pa bzhi la tsa tv'arya pra m'a na zhes tshad med pa bzhi yin te /
analyzed: tshad med pa bzhi la tsa tv'arya pra m'a na zhes tshad med pa bzhi yin te /
translated: The four immeasurables are called the four immeasurables catvari apramanaani because they are immeasurable aprameya.

original: sems can grangs med dpag tu med pa la byams pa dang snying rje dang dga' ba dang btang snyoms kyis khyab par sgom pas tshad med pa bzhi zhes bya /
analyzed: sems can grangs med dpag tu med pa la byams pa dang snying rje dang dga' ba dang btang snyoms kyis khyab par sgom pas tshad med pa bzhi zhes bya /
translated: They are called the four immeasurables because one meditates on the immeasurable aprameya sentient beings who are as numerous as the limits of space with love, compassion, joy and impartiality.

original: bsam gtan dang snyoms par 'jug pa la sogs pa'i ming la dhy'a na zhes bya ba dhyee tsitta yan zhes bya ste /
analyzed: bsam gtan dang snyoms par 'jug pa la sogs pa'i ming la dhy'a na zhes bya ba dhyee tsitta yan zhes bya ste /
translated: The term dhyana for concentration, meditative absorption, and so on is dhyeya-citta-ayanam.

original: sems pa la bya /
analyzed: sems pa la bya /
translated: It means “that which causes the mind to be directed.”

original: mi rtag pa 'am stong pa la sogs pa lta bu gcig pa la bsam pa'i gtan pa bcas te bsgoms pas na bsam gtan zhes bya /
analyzed: mi rtag pa 'am stong pa la sogs pa lta bu gcig pa la bsam pa'i gtan pa bcas te bsgoms pas na bsam gtan zhes bya /
translated: Since one meditates by directing the mind to a single object such as impermanence or emptiness, it is called dhyana.🔽The term anagamya means “not capable of” (na) “approaching” (agama).

original: aa n'a g'a mya zhes bya ba na sya a'a g'a mya zhes bya ba ni bsam gtan dang po la snyoms par 'jug pa'i sems kyis khams gsum gyi nyon @146b mongs pa thams cad spong mi nus pa med pas na mi lcogs pa med ba zhes bya /
analyzed: aa n'a g'a mya zhes bya ba na sya a'a g'a mya zhes bya ba ni bsam gtan dang po la snyoms par 'jug pa'i sems kyis khams gsum gyi nyon @146b mongs pa thams cad spong mi nus pa med pas na mi lcogs pa med ba zhes bya /
translated: Since the mind that enters the first dhyana is not capable of eliminating all the afflictions of the three realms, it is called the “not capable of approaching.”

original: dhy'a n'anta ra zhes bya ba dhy'a na ni bsam gtan /
analyzed: dhy'a n'anta ra zhes bya ba dhy'a na ni bsam gtan /
translated: The term dhyanantara means “intermediate dhyana.”🔽Dhyana is concentration.

original: aanta ri bye brag gam khyad par te /
analyzed: aanta ri bye brag gam khyad par te /
translated: Antara means “particular” or “special.”

original: bsam gtan dang po rtog pa dang bcas dpyod pa dang bcas pa yin pa'i nang na /
analyzed: bsam gtan dang po rtog pa dang bcas dpyod pa dang bcas pa yin pa'i nang na /
translated: Among the concentrations of the first dhyana, which are associated with investigation and analysis,

original: bsam gtan khyad par can ni rtog pa ni med dpyod pa tsam du zad de bye brag tu 'phags pas tshangs pa chen po'i go 'phang thob pa'i phyir bsam gtan khyad par can zhes bya /
analyzed: bsam gtan khyad par can ni rtog pa ni med dpyod pa tsam du zad de bye brag tu 'phags pas tshangs pa chen po'i go 'phang thob pa'i phyir bsam gtan khyad par can zhes bya /
translated: The special meditative stabilization is called special meditative stabilization because it is superior to the other meditative stabilizations since it is the end of investigation and the beginning of analysis.

original: sa manta ka zhes bya ba sa manta bha ba tv'at+sa manta ka zhes bya ste /🔽sa manta na nye ba /
analyzed: sa manta ka zhes bya ba sa manta bha ba tv'at+sa manta ka zhes bya ste / sa manta na nye ba /
translated: The Sanskrit for special meditative stabilization is dhyānāntara.

original: bha ba ni 'byung ba'am gnas pa lta bu la bya ste /
analyzed: bha ba ni 'byung ba'am gnas pa lta bu la bya ste /
translated: Dhyāna means meditative stabilization and antara means near.

original: spyir na bsam gtan dang gzugs med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa la mnyam par gzhag pa'i phyir sngar nas shom pa'i sems kyi ming ste nyer bsngogs zhes bya'o //🔽moo la zhes bya ba /
analyzed: spyir na bsam gtan dang gzugs med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa la mnyam par gzhag pa'i phyir sngar nas shom pa'i sems kyi ming ste nyer bsngogs zhes bya'o // moo la zhes bya ba /
translated: In general, it is called access concentration because it is the name of the mind that prepares for meditative stabilization and formless meditative attainment.

original: m'u le bha ba tv'admoo la zhes bya ste /🔽m'u la rtsa ba 'am /
analyzed: m'u le bha ba tv'admoo la zhes bya ste / m'u la rtsa ba 'am /
translated: The Sanskrit for the first concentration is maula.

original: gzhi 'am dngos /🔽bha ba ni 'byung ba 'am gnas pa ste don dang sbyar na /
analyzed: gzhi 'am dngos / bha ba ni 'byung ba 'am gnas pa ste don dang sbyar na /
translated: Maula means root, basis or substance.

original: bsam gtan dang snyoms par 'jug pa dngos la bya bas dngos gzhi zhes bya /
analyzed: bsam gtan dang snyoms par 'jug pa dngos la bya bas dngos gzhi zhes bya /
translated: In general, it is called actual basis because it is the actual meditative stabilization and meditative attainment.

original: sa m'a patti zhes bya ba sems dang sems las byung ba'i tshogs dmigs pa gcig la 'du zhing gnyis mnyam par byed pa'i ming ste snyoms par 'jug pa zhes bya /
analyzed: sa m'a patti zhes bya ba sems dang sems las byung ba'i tshogs dmigs pa gcig la 'du zhing gnyis mnyam par byed pa'i ming ste snyoms par 'jug pa zhes bya /
translated: Samāpatti is the name for the assembly of mind and mental factors that enter into a single object and make two things equal, and is called meditative absorption.

original: sa m'a dhi zhes pa sa m'a dhi yan te aa ne na zhes bya ste /
analyzed: sa m'a dhi zhes pa sa m'a dhi yan te aa ne na zhes bya ste /
translated: Samādhi is samādhyanena.

original: ting nge 'dzin gyi mthus sems dang sems las byung ba'i rgyud dmigs pa gcig la sdud cing mi g-yo bar ting nge 'dzin 'jog pas na ting nge 'dzin zhes bya /
analyzed: ting nge 'dzin gyi mthus sems dang sems las byung ba'i rgyud dmigs pa gcig la sdud cing mi g-yo bar ting nge 'dzin 'jog pas na ting nge 'dzin zhes bya /
translated: Since the continuum of mind and mental factors is concentrated on a single object by the power of meditative absorption and meditative absorption is placed without wavering, it is called meditative absorption.

original: ni ro dha sa m'a patti zhes bya ba 'du shes dang tshor ba 'gog cing lus rdo rje la sogs pa cis kyang mi shigs par 'byung ba chen po rnams mthun par sgrub pa la yang bya /
analyzed: ni ro dha sa m'a patti zhes bya ba 'du shes dang tshor ba 'gog cing lus rdo rje la sogs pa cis kyang mi shigs par 'byung ba chen po rnams mthun par sgrub pa la yang bya /
translated: Nirodha-samāpatti is the cessation of discernment and feeling and the concordant achievement of the great elements, such that the body is indestructible by any means, such as by a vajra.

original: zhi ba la gnas par 'jug pa'i sems kyis tshor ba dang 'du shes 'gog pa snyoms par 'jug pa la yang bya bas na 'gog pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa zhes bya /
analyzed: zhi ba la gnas par 'jug pa'i sems kyis tshor ba dang 'du shes 'gog pa snyoms par 'jug pa la yang bya bas na 'gog pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa zhes bya /
translated: Since it is also the meditative absorption of the cessation of feeling and discernment by a mind that is engaged in abiding in peace, it is called the meditative absorption of cessation.

original: aa sam dzny'a sa m'a patti zhes bya ba 'du shes med pa'i sems kyis snyoms par 'jug pa yin pas na 'du shes med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa zhes kyang bya /
analyzed: aa sam dzny'a sa m'a patti zhes bya ba 'du shes med pa'i sems kyis snyoms par 'jug pa yin pas na 'du shes med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa zhes kyang bya /
translated: Asamjnisamāpatti means the meditative attainment of nondiscernment because it is meditative attainment through the mind of nondiscernment.

original: yang gcig tu na snyoms par 'jug pa de 'du shes med pas na 'du shes med pa'i snyoms pa'i 'jug pa zhes bya /🔽aashtoo bi moksha zhes bya ba gzugs can gyis gzugs mthong ngo zhes bya ba la sogs pa mi sdug pa sgom pa la @147a * //
analyzed: yang gcig tu na snyoms par 'jug pa de 'du shes med pas na 'du shes med pa'i snyoms pa'i 'jug pa zhes bya / aashtoo bi moksha zhes bya ba gzugs can gyis gzugs mthong ngo zhes bya ba la sogs pa mi sdug pa sgom pa la @147a * //
translated: Or, since that meditative attainment is nondiscernment, it is called the meditative attainment of nondiscernment.🔽Aṣṭau vimokṣāḥ means the eight liberations.

original: sogs pas gzugs las skyo zhing chags pa las grol bar byed pas na rnam par thar pa brgyad ces bya /
analyzed: sogs pas gzugs las skyo zhing chags pa las grol bar byed pas na rnam par thar pa brgyad ces bya /
translated: The eight liberations are called the eight liberations because they liberate from attachment to form and so on through meditating on repulsiveness and so on.

original: aasht'a bhi bha b'a ya ta na zhes bya ba nang gzugs su 'du shes pas phyi rol gyi gzugs kha dog bzang po dang / ngan pa la sogs pa mthong nas gzugs de dag zil gyis mnan te shes par byed pas na zil gyis gnon pa'i skye mched brgyad ces bya /🔽da sha kri t+sn'a ya ta na zhes bya ba phyogs bcu ma lus par sa la sogs par mos shing yid la byed pa'i bsam gtan gyi ming ste /
analyzed: aasht'a bhi bha b'a ya ta na zhes bya ba nang gzugs su 'du shes pas phyi rol gyi gzugs kha dog bzang po dang / ngan pa la sogs pa mthong nas gzugs de dag zil gyis mnan te shes par byed pas na zil gyis gnon pa'i skye mched brgyad ces bya / da sha kri t+sn'a ya ta na zhes bya ba phyogs bcu ma lus par sa la sogs par mos shing yid la byed pa'i bsam gtan gyi ming ste /
translated: The eight spheres of mastery are called aṣṭāv abhibhvāyatanāni.🔽The ten spheres of totality are called daśakṛtsnāyatanāni.

original: zad par gyi skye mched bcu zhes bya /🔽na b'a nu p'urba bi ha ra sa m'a patti zhes bya ba /
analyzed: zad par gyi skye mched bcu zhes bya / na b'a nu p'urba bi ha ra sa m'a patti zhes bya ba /
translated: The nine serial absorptions are called navānupūrvasamāpattayaḥ.

original: bsam gtan bzhi dang / gzugs med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa bzhi dang 'gog pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa dang dgu la mthar gyis gnas shing 'jug pa'i ming ste /
analyzed: bsam gtan bzhi dang / gzugs med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa bzhi dang 'gog pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa dang dgu la mthar gyis gnas shing 'jug pa'i ming ste /
translated: The four absorptions, the four formless meditative attainments, and the meditative attainment of cessation.🔽The four formless meditative attainments are called ārūpyasamāpattayaḥ.

original: mthar gyis gnas pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa dgu zhes bya /
analyzed: mthar gyis gnas pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa dgu zhes bya /
translated: The meditative attainment of cessation is called nirodhasamāpatti.

original: rnam par thar pa'i sgo dang gzungs dang mngon par shes pa'i ming la /
analyzed: rnam par thar pa'i sgo dang gzungs dang mngon par shes pa'i ming la /
translated: The names of the doors of liberation, the powers of retention, and the levels of deeper discernment:

original: tri ni bi moksha mu kha zhes bya ba rnam par thar pa'i sgo gsum yin te /
analyzed: tri ni bi moksha mu kha zhes bya ba rnam par thar pa'i sgo gsum yin te /
translated: Tri means door of liberation.🔽There are three doors of liberation: emptiness, absence of characteristics, and absence of expectancy.

original: stong pa nyid dang mtshan ma med pa dang smon pa med pa gsum gyis mya ngan las 'da' bar 'gyur zhing 'khor ba las thar pa'i sgo yin pas na rnam par thar pa'i sgo gsum zhes bya /
analyzed: stong pa nyid dang mtshan ma med pa dang smon pa med pa gsum gyis mya ngan las 'da' bar 'gyur zhing 'khor ba las thar pa'i sgo yin pas na rnam par thar pa'i sgo gsum zhes bya /
translated: Since one attains nirvana through these three and they are the doors to liberation from samsara, they are called the three doors of liberation.

original: dh'a ra na zhes bya ba gzungs yin te /
analyzed: dh'a ra na zhes bya ba gzungs yin te /
translated: Dhāraṇī means power of retention.

original: dran pa dang shes bzhin gyis chos kyi tshig dang don mi rjed par 'dzin pas na gzungs zhes bya /
analyzed: dran pa dang shes bzhin gyis chos kyi tshig dang don mi rjed par 'dzin pas na gzungs zhes bya /
translated: Since one retains the words and meanings of the teachings without forgetting them through mindfulness and alertness, this is called a power of retention.🔽Ṣaḍabhijñā means the six levels of deeper discernment.

original: sha da bhi dzny'a zhes bya ba mngon par shes pa drug yin te aa bhi ni aa bhi ta ste mngon pa /🔽dzny'a ni shes pa la bya ste /
analyzed: sha da bhi dzny'a zhes bya ba mngon par shes pa drug yin te aa bhi ni aa bhi ta ste mngon pa /🔽dzny'a ni shes pa la bya ste /
translated: Abhi means manifest and jñāna means knowledge.

original: lha'i mig dang / lha'i rna ba dang / pha rol gyi sems shes pa dang / sngon gyi gnas rjes su dran pa'i shes pa dang / rdzu 'phrul gyi bya ba shes pa dang / zag pa zad pa shes pa dang drug mngon sum du mdzad pas na mngon par shes pa drug ces bya /
analyzed: lha'i mig dang / lha'i rna ba dang / pha rol gyi sems shes pa dang / sngon gyi gnas rjes su dran pa'i shes pa dang / rdzu 'phrul gyi bya ba shes pa dang / zag pa zad pa shes pa dang drug mngon sum du mdzad pas na mngon par shes pa drug ces bya /
translated: The six kinds of preternatural knowledge are called the six kinds of preternatural knowledge because they are the direct realization of the six kinds of preternatural knowledge: the knowledge of the divine eye, the knowledge of the divine ear, the knowledge of the minds of others, the knowledge of recollecting past lives, the knowledge of the performance of miracles and the knowledge of the extinction of defilements.

original: stong pa nyid bco brgyad la /🔽aa dhy'atma sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba aa dhy'atma ni nang /
analyzed: stong pa nyid bco brgyad la / aa dhy'atma sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba aa dhy'atma ni nang /
translated: The eighteen kinds of emptiness

original: sh'u n+ya t'a ni stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: sh'u n+ya t'a ni stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: The emptiness of the inner

original: nang gi chos mig dang / rna ba dang / sna dang / lce dang / lus dang / yid rnams ther zug tu gnas pa'ang ma yin /
analyzed: nang gi chos mig dang / rna ba dang / sna dang / lce dang / lus dang / yid rnams ther zug tu gnas pa'ang ma yin /
translated: The emptiness of the inner means that the inner phenomena of the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body and mental faculty are not permanent.

original: 'jig par 'gyur ba'ang ma yin pa'i phyir don dam par na mig la sogs pa la dngos po med pas na nang stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: 'jig par 'gyur ba'ang ma yin pa'i phyir don dam par na mig la sogs pa la dngos po med pas na nang stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Because they are not destroyed, in the ultimate truth, the eyes and so forth are devoid of things, and so it is called the emptiness of the inner.

original: ba hirdh'a sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya @147b ba phyi stong pa nyid ces bya ba yin te /
analyzed: ba hirdh'a sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya @147b ba phyi stong pa nyid ces bya ba yin te /
translated: The emptiness of the outer🔽The emptiness of the outer means that outer phenomena such as forms, sounds, smells, tastes, textures and mental objects are not permanent.

original: phyi'i chos gzugs dang / sgra dang / dri dang / ro dang / reg dang / chos rnams ther zug tu gnas pa'ang ma yin /
analyzed: phyi'i chos gzugs dang / sgra dang / dri dang / ro dang / reg dang / chos rnams ther zug tu gnas pa'ang ma yin /
translated: Because external phenomena—forms, sounds, smells, tastes, textures, and mental objects—are not permanent,

original: 'jig par 'gyur ba yang ma yin pa'i phyir don dam par na gzugs la sogs pa la dngos po med pas na phyi stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: 'jig par 'gyur ba yang ma yin pa'i phyir don dam par na gzugs la sogs pa la dngos po med pas na phyi stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: and because they do not disintegrate, ultimately forms and so forth are not things. Therefore, it is called the emptiness of the external.

original: aadhy'atma ba hirdh'a sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba phyi nang stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: aadhy'atma ba hirdh'a sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba phyi nang stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: Adhyātmabahirdhāśūnyatā means the emptiness of the external and the internal.

original: phyi nang gi skye mched bcu gnyis don dam par na gzung ba dang 'dzin pa gnyis ka med de /
analyzed: phyi nang gi skye mched bcu gnyis don dam par na gzung ba dang 'dzin pa gnyis ka med de /
translated: Ultimately, the twelve internal and external sense sources are devoid of both the apprehended and the apprehender.

original: yul dang yul gyi tshul dang bral bas na phyi nang stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: yul dang yul gyi tshul dang bral bas na phyi nang stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Because they are free from the mode of object and object-possessor, it is called the emptiness of the external and the internal.

original: sh'un+ya t'a sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba stong pa nyid stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: sh'un+ya t'a sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba stong pa nyid stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: Śūnyatāśūnyatā means the emptiness of emptiness.

original: chos thams cad kyi stong pa nyid kyi stong pa nyid stong pa ste /
analyzed: chos thams cad kyi stong pa nyid kyi stong pa nyid stong pa ste /
translated: The emptiness of the emptiness of all phenomena is empty.

original: gzhan gyis stong par byar med pas na stong pa nyid stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: gzhan gyis stong par byar med pas na stong pa nyid stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Because it cannot be emptied by another, it is called the emptiness of emptiness.

original: ma h'a sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba chen po stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: ma h'a sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba chen po stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: Mahashunyata means “great emptiness.”

original: snod kyi 'jig rten pa'i dkyil 'khor chen po phyogs bcur stong pas na chen po stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: snod kyi 'jig rten pa'i dkyil 'khor chen po phyogs bcur stong pas na chen po stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Since the great mandala of the world is empty in the ten directions, it is called “great emptiness.”

original: pa ra m'artha sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba don dam pa stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: pa ra m'artha sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba don dam pa stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: Paramartha-shunyata means “emptiness of ultimate reality.”

original: don dam pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa la bya /
analyzed: don dam pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa la bya /
translated: It refers to ultimate nirvana.

original: don dam pa nyid la yang stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: don dam pa nyid la yang stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Ultimate reality is also called “emptiness.”

original: sam skri ta sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba 'dus byas stong pa nyid ces bya ba yin te /
analyzed: sam skri ta sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba 'dus byas stong pa nyid ces bya ba yin te /
translated: Samskrita-shunyata means “emptiness of the conditioned.”

original: 'dus byas ni khams gsum du gtogs so cog la bya /
analyzed: 'dus byas ni khams gsum du gtogs so cog la bya /
translated: The conditioned refers to everything included in the three realms.

original: khams gsum du gtogs pa yang sgyu ma dang 'dra ste /🔽skye ba dang gnas pa dang 'gag pa dang bral zhing stong pas na 'dus byas stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: khams gsum du gtogs pa yang sgyu ma dang 'dra ste / skye ba dang gnas pa dang 'gag pa dang bral zhing stong pas na 'dus byas stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: The three realms are like an illusion.🔽Since they are free from arising, abiding, and ceasing and are empty, they are called “the emptiness of the conditioned.”

original: aa sam skri ta sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba 'dus ma byas stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: aa sam skri ta sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba 'dus ma byas stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: Asamskrita-shunyata means “emptiness of the unconditioned.”

original: 'dus ma byas ni nam mkha' dang de bzhin nyid dang 'gog pa rnam pa gnyis rgyu dang rkyen gyis grub pa ma yin pa 'dus ma byas ni gzhi rang bzhin gyis stong bas na 'dus ma byas stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: 'dus ma byas ni nam mkha' dang de bzhin nyid dang 'gog pa rnam pa gnyis rgyu dang rkyen gyis grub pa ma yin pa 'dus ma byas ni gzhi rang bzhin gyis stong bas na 'dus ma byas stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: The uncompounded is space, suchness and the two kinds of cessation. It is not established by causes and conditions. Since the basis is empty by nature, it is called the emptiness of the uncompounded.

original: aa tyanta sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba mtha' las 'das pa stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: aa tyanta sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba mtha' las 'das pa stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: Atyanta-shunyata means the emptiness of that which transcends limits.

original: rtag pa dang chad pa dang yod pa dang med pa la sogs pa'i mtha' dang bral bas na mtha' las 'das pa stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: rtag pa dang chad pa dang yod pa dang med pa la sogs pa'i mtha' dang bral bas na mtha' las 'das pa stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Since it is free from the limits of permanence, annihilation, existence, nonexistence and so forth, it is called the emptiness of that which transcends limits.

original: aa na ba r'a gr'a sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba thog ma dang tha ma med pa stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: aa na ba r'a gr'a sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba thog ma dang tha ma med pa stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: Ananta-shunyata means the emptiness of that which has no beginning or end.

original: 'khor ba thog ma dang tha ma med pa la dbus kyang stong pas thog ma dang tha ma med pa stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: 'khor ba thog ma dang tha ma med pa la dbus kyang stong pas thog ma dang tha ma med pa stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Since the beginning, end and middle of samsara are empty, it is called the emptiness of that which has no beginning or end.

original: aa na ba k'a ra sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba aa ba ta ka ra na ni dor ba ste dor ba med pas na aa na ba ka ra zhes bya ste /🔽bum pa'i nang du chu @148a * //🔽blugs pa las /
analyzed: aa na ba k'a ra sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba aa ba ta ka ra na ni dor ba ste dor ba med pas na aa na ba ka ra zhes bya ste / bum pa'i nang du chu @148a * // blugs pa las /
translated: Anantaparyantaśūnyatā means that since there is nothing to discard, there is no discarding.🔽It is not like when water is poured into a vase,🔽and when the water is poured out,

original: chu pho nas stong par gyur pa lta bu ma yin gyis /
analyzed: chu pho nas stong par gyur pa lta bu ma yin gyis /
translated: it becomes empty.

original: chos thams cad ye nas rang bzhin gyis stong ste /
analyzed: chos thams cad ye nas rang bzhin gyis stong ste /
translated: All phenomena are primordially empty by nature.

original: dor zhing bsal ba med pas na dor ba med pa stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: dor zhing bsal ba med pas na dor ba med pa stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Since there is nothing to discard or remove, it is called the emptiness of no discarding.

original: pra kri ti sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba rang bzhin gyis stong pa nyid de chos thams cad nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dang de bzhin gshegs pas kyang ma mdzad de /
analyzed: pra kri ti sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba rang bzhin gyis stong pa nyid de chos thams cad nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dang de bzhin gshegs pas kyang ma mdzad de /
translated: Prakṛtiśūnyatā means the emptiness of the nature. Since all phenomena were not created by śrāvakas, pratyekabuddhas, or tathāgatas,

original: rang bzhin gyis 'dus byas kyang ma yin /
analyzed: rang bzhin gyis 'dus byas kyang ma yin /
translated: they are not compounded by nature.

original: 'dus ma byas kyang ma yin pas na rang bzhin gyis stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: 'dus ma byas kyang ma yin pas na rang bzhin gyis stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Since they are not uncompounded, it is called the emptiness of the nature.

original: sarbba dharmma sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba chos thams cad stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: sarbba dharmma sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba chos thams cad stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: Sarvadharmaśūnyatā means the emptiness of all phenomena.

original: chos thams cad ces bya ba ni phung po dang khams dang skye mched la sogs pa 'dus byas dang 'dus ma byas kyi chos thams cad la bya /
analyzed: chos thams cad ces bya ba ni phung po dang khams dang skye mched la sogs pa 'dus byas dang 'dus ma byas kyi chos thams cad la bya /
translated: All phenomena refers to all conditioned and unconditioned phenomena such as the aggregates, elements, sense spheres and so on.

original: de thams cad stong pas na chos thams cad stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: de thams cad stong pas na chos thams cad stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Since all of them are empty, it is called the emptiness of all phenomena.

original: sva laksha na sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba rang gi mtshan nyid stong pa nyid yin te /🔽rang gi mtshan nyid ni gzugs su rung bas na gzugs myong ba'i mtshan nyid pas na tshor ba /
analyzed: sva laksha na sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba rang gi mtshan nyid stong pa nyid yin te / rang gi mtshan nyid ni gzugs su rung bas na gzugs myong ba'i mtshan nyid pas na tshor ba /
translated: Svabhāvaśūnyatā means the emptiness of its own characteristic.

original: mtshan mar 'dzin pas na 'du shes zhes bya ba la sogs pa chos so so rang gi mtshan nyid kyang brtag pa tsam du zad de yongs su grub pa med pas na rang gi mtshan nyid stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: mtshan mar 'dzin pas na 'du shes zhes bya ba la sogs pa chos so so rang gi mtshan nyid kyang brtag pa tsam du zad de yongs su grub pa med pas na rang gi mtshan nyid stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: The individual characteristics of phenomena are that because it is suitable as form, it is form; because it has the characteristic of experiencing, it is feeling; because it apprehends signs, it is discernment and so on. Since even the individual characteristics of each phenomenon are mere imputation and do not exist ultimately, it is called the emptiness of its own characteristic.

original: aa nu pa lambha sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba mi dmigs pa stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: aa nu pa lambha sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba mi dmigs pa stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: Anupalambhaśūnyatā means the emptiness of nonobservation.

original: 'das pa dang ma 'ongs pa dang da ltar gyi chos dus gsum du gtogs pa'i rnam pa dmigs su med pa la yang dngos po gud na med pas na mi dmigs pa stong pa nyid ces bya /🔽aa bh'a ba sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba dngos po med pa stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: 'das pa dang ma 'ongs pa dang da ltar gyi chos dus gsum du gtogs pa'i rnam pa dmigs su med pa la yang dngos po gud na med pas na mi dmigs pa stong pa nyid ces bya / aa bh'a ba sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba dngos po med pa stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: The emptiness of nonapprehension refers to the fact that the aspects of phenomena of the past, present and future, which are included in the three times, are not apprehended, but since there is no other entity, it is called the emptiness of nonapprehension.

original: dngos po med pa las yang dngos por gzung du rung ba'i rang bzhin med pas na dngos po med pa stong pa nyid ces bya /🔽sva bh'a ba sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: dngos po med pa las yang dngos por gzung du rung ba'i rang bzhin med pas na dngos po med pa stong pa nyid ces bya / sva bh'a ba sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: The emptiness of nonthings refers to the fact that there is no nature that can be apprehended as an entity from a nonthing.

original: 'du 'phrod las byung ba'i chos rnams rang dbang du mi skye ste /
analyzed: 'du 'phrod las byung ba'i chos rnams rang dbang du mi skye ste /
translated: The emptiness of essential nature refers to the fact that phenomena that arise from a combination of causes and conditions do not arise independently.

original: rten cing 'brel te 'byung ba yin pas ngo bo nyid med pa'i phyir ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid ces bya /🔽aa bh'a ba sva bh'a ba sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba ;
analyzed: rten cing 'brel te 'byung ba yin pas ngo bo nyid med pa'i phyir ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid ces bya / aa bh'a ba sva bh'a ba sh'u n+ya t'a zhes bya ba ;
translated: Since they are dependently arisen, they have no essential nature and are therefore called the emptiness of essential nature.

original: dngos po med pa ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid yin te /
analyzed: dngos po med pa ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid yin te /
translated: The emptiness of the essential nature of nonthings refers to the fact that

original: dngos po med par rtogs pa'i mthong ba dang shes pa ni dngos po med pa'i ngo bo nyid ces bya /
analyzed: dngos po med par rtogs pa'i mthong ba dang shes pa ni dngos po med pa'i ngo bo nyid ces bya /
translated: The seeing and knowing that realizes the absence of things is called the “nature of the absence of things.”

original: mthong ba dang shes pa 'di gnyis ka yang mthong bas kyang ma byas shes pas kyang ma byas te rang bzhin gyis stong pa'i phyir dngos po med pa'i ngo bo @148b nyid stong pa nyid ces bya /
analyzed: mthong ba dang shes pa 'di gnyis ka yang mthong bas kyang ma byas shes pas kyang ma byas te rang bzhin gyis stong pa'i phyir dngos po med pa'i ngo bo @148b nyid stong pa nyid ces bya /
translated: Neither seeing nor knowing creates this seeing and knowing, because they are empty of inherent nature. Therefore, it is called the “emptiness of the nature of the absence of things.”

original: zhi gnas dang lhag mthong la sogs pa'i ming la /
analyzed: zhi gnas dang lhag mthong la sogs pa'i ming la /
translated: Names for śamatha, vipaśyanā, and so on

original: sha ma stha zhes bya ba sha me bsti ti sha ma stha zhes bya ste /
analyzed: sha ma stha zhes bya ba sha me bsti ti sha ma stha zhes bya ste /
translated: Śamatha is called śamatha.

original: sha ma ni zhi ba dang / stha ni gnas pa ste /
analyzed: sha ma ni zhi ba dang / stha ni gnas pa ste /
translated: Śama means “peace” and tha means “to abide.”

original: gzugs la sogs pa yul gyis sems g-yeng bzhi bar byas nas bsam gtan gang sgom pa de la sems rtse gcig tu khugs pa'i ming yin pas na zhig nas zhes bya /
analyzed: gzugs la sogs pa yul gyis sems g-yeng bzhi bar byas nas bsam gtan gang sgom pa de la sems rtse gcig tu khugs pa'i ming yin pas na zhig nas zhes bya /
translated: It is the name for the mind being focused one-pointedly on whatever meditative concentration is being cultivated, having pacified the mind’s distraction by objects such as forms.

original: bi pa shya na zhes bya ba bi ni bi she sha ste /
analyzed: bi pa shya na zhes bya ba bi ni bi she sha ste /
translated: Vipaśyanā is called vipaśyanā.

original: khyad par ram lhag pa /
analyzed: khyad par ram lhag pa /
translated: Vi means “special” or “extra.”

original: pa shya na ni mthong ba 'am lta ba la bya /
analyzed: pa shya na ni mthong ba 'am lta ba la bya /
translated: Paśyanā means “to see” or “to view.”

original: spyir na shes rab kyis dngos po'i rang bzhin lhag par rtogs pa'i rang bzhin te lhag mthong zhes bya /
analyzed: spyir na shes rab kyis dngos po'i rang bzhin lhag par rtogs pa'i rang bzhin te lhag mthong zhes bya /
translated: In general, insight is the nature of the special realization of the nature of things, and is called “special insight.”

original: yo ga zhes bya ba yu dzir yo ga zhes bya ste /
analyzed: yo ga zhes bya ba yu dzir yo ga zhes bya ste /
translated: Yoga is called “yujir yoga.”

original: zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zung du 'brel pa'i bsam gtan gyi ming ste rnal 'byor zhes bya /
analyzed: zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zung du 'brel pa'i bsam gtan gyi ming ste rnal 'byor zhes bya /
translated: It is the name of the concentration that is the union of serenity and insight, and is called “yoga.”

original: yo ni sha ma na sk'a ra zhes bya ba yo ni au p'a y'a ste thabs sam rgyud la bya /
analyzed: yo ni sha ma na sk'a ra zhes bya ba yo ni au p'a y'a ste thabs sam rgyud la bya /
translated: Yo is called “upayakausala,” which means “means” or “cause.”

original: sha ni sha na sa ti zhes bya ste /
analyzed: sha ni sha na sa ti zhes bya ste /
translated: Sha is called “shashana sathi,” which means

original: thabs dang tshul de nyid la spyod cing ston pa la bya ste /
analyzed: thabs dang tshul de nyid la spyod cing ston pa la bya ste /
translated: to practice and teach just those means and methods.

original: spyir na mi sdug pa sgom pas 'dod chags gzhil ba dang / rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba sgom pas gti mug spangs pa la sogs pa ste /
analyzed: spyir na mi sdug pa sgom pas 'dod chags gzhil ba dang / rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba sgom pas gti mug spangs pa la sogs pa ste /
translated: In general, it is the name of the meditation on the proper methods, such as the pacification of attachment through meditation on the unattractive, and the abandonment of delusion through meditation on dependent origination.

original: thabs tshul bzhin du sgom pa'i ming yin pas na tshul bzhin yid la byed pa zhes bya /
analyzed: thabs tshul bzhin du sgom pa'i ming yin pas na tshul bzhin yid la byed pa zhes bya /
translated: Therefore, it is called “proper mental application.”

original: 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi rnam pa bcu drug du phye ba la sogs pa'i ming la /
analyzed: 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi rnam pa bcu drug du phye ba la sogs pa'i ming la /
translated: The names of the four noble truths divided into sixteen aspects and so forth.

original: tsa tu r'a rya satya zhes bya ba tsa tur ni bzhi /
analyzed: tsa tu r'a rya satya zhes bya ba tsa tur ni bzhi /
translated: Catvāri means four.

original: a'arya ni 'phags pa /
analyzed: a'arya ni 'phags pa /
translated: Ārya means noble.

original: satya ni bden pa ste sdug bsngal dang kun 'byung dang 'gog pa dang lam bzhi ji ltar 'phags pa rnams kyis bden par gzigs pa de bzhin du /
analyzed: satya ni bden pa ste sdug bsngal dang kun 'byung dang 'gog pa dang lam bzhi ji ltar 'phags pa rnams kyis bden par gzigs pa de bzhin du /
translated: Satya means truth. The four noble truths are the truths of suffering, origin, cessation, and path.

original: so so'i skye bo phyin ci log dang bcas pas bden par mi mthong bas na 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi zhes bya /
analyzed: so so'i skye bo phyin ci log dang bcas pas bden par mi mthong bas na 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi zhes bya /
translated: They are called the four noble truths because ordinary beings, who are subject to error, do not see them as they are seen by the noble ones.

original: du:kha satya zhes pa sdug bsngal gyi bden pa ste /
analyzed: du:kha satya zhes pa sdug bsngal gyi bden pa ste /
translated: The truth of suffering is called duḥkha-satya.

original: zag pa dang bcas pa'i 'du byed la yid du 'ong ba rnams ni 'gyur ba'i sdug bsngal gyis sdug bsngal bar 'gyur /
analyzed: zag pa dang bcas pa'i 'du byed la yid du 'ong ba rnams ni 'gyur ba'i sdug bsngal gyis sdug bsngal bar 'gyur /
translated: Pleasant contaminated formations are suffering because of the suffering of change.

original: yid du mi 'ong ba rnams ni sdug bsngal gyis sdug bsngal bar 'gyur la ;
analyzed: yid du mi 'ong ba rnams ni sdug bsngal gyis sdug bsngal bar 'gyur la ;
translated: Unpleasant ones are suffering because of the suffering of suffering.

original: de las ma gtogs pa'i chos gzhan 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal gyis sdug bsngal bar 'gyur te /
analyzed: de las ma gtogs pa'i chos gzhan 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal gyis sdug bsngal bar 'gyur te /
translated: Other phenomena, which are not included in those two, are suffering because of the suffering of formations.

original: phung po lnga sdug bsngal gsum dang ldan pas na sdug bsngal gyi bden pa zhes bya /
analyzed: phung po lnga sdug bsngal gsum dang ldan pas na sdug bsngal gyi bden pa zhes bya /
translated: The five aggregates are called the truth of suffering because they possess the three kinds of suffering.

original: sa mu da ya zhes bya ba sa mu da ya tya sm'ad karmma kle sha laksha n'ad ces 'byung bas na las dang nyon mongs @149a * //
analyzed: sa mu da ya zhes bya ba sa mu da ya tya sm'ad karmma kle sha laksha n'ad ces 'byung bas na las dang nyon mongs @149a * //
translated: Samudaya means samudayate, that is, the characteristic of karma and affliction.

original: pa'i mtshan nyid de dag las sdug bsngal 'byung ba la bya ste /
analyzed: pa'i mtshan nyid de dag las sdug bsngal 'byung ba la bya ste /
translated: It is the origin of suffering because suffering arises from those.

original: de las nyon mongs pa ni srid pa gsum du slar skye zhing 'byung bar 'dod pa'i 'dod chags la sogs pa la bya /
analyzed: de las nyon mongs pa ni srid pa gsum du slar skye zhing 'byung bar 'dod pa'i 'dod chags la sogs pa la bya /
translated: Affliction refers to attachment and so on that desire to be born again in the three existences.

original: las ni mi dge ba dang dge ba zag pa dang bcas pa la bya ste /🔽kun 'byung ba zhes bya ste /
analyzed: las ni mi dge ba dang dge ba zag pa dang bcas pa la bya ste / kun 'byung ba zhes bya ste /
translated: Karma refers to nonvirtue and contaminated virtue.🔽It is called origin because it is the origin of suffering.🔽 Nirodha means nirodhyante asmin sarvakleśā iti.

original: ni ro dha zhes bya ba ni ro dhyante aasmin sarba kle sha ai ti zhes 'byung bas 'gog pa thob pas nyon mongs pa thams cad 'gag pa'i phyir 'gog pa zhes bya /
analyzed: ni ro dha zhes bya ba ni ro dhyante aasmin sarba kle sha ai ti zhes 'byung bas 'gog pa thob pas nyon mongs pa thams cad 'gag pa'i phyir 'gog pa zhes bya /
translated: It is called cessation because all afflictions cease through attaining cessation.

original: m'argga zhes bya ba m'argga yanti aa ne na ni ro dha mi ti zhes 'byung ste /
