analyzed: m'argga zhes bya ba m'argga yanti aa ne na ni ro dha mi ti zhes 'byung ste /
translated: Marga means margyate anena nirvanam iti.

original: lam des 'gog pa tshol ba 'am mtshon pa 'am dmigs pa 'am 'thob par 'gyur ba la bya ste lam zhes bya /
analyzed: lam des 'gog pa tshol ba 'am mtshon pa 'am dmigs pa 'am 'thob par 'gyur ba la bya ste lam zhes bya /
translated: The path is that by which one searches for, or is directed to, or focuses on, or attains cessation.

original: aa ni tya zhes bya ba pra tye yandhi na tv'a da aa ni tya zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: aa ni tya zhes bya ba pra tye yandhi na tv'a da aa ni tya zhes 'byung ste /
translated: The syllable a is anityatva, which means “impermanence.”

original: rkyen la rag las pa'i phyir mi rtag pa ste /
analyzed: rkyen la rag las pa'i phyir mi rtag pa ste /
translated: It is impermanent because it depends on conditions.

original: rkyen tshogs na ni 'byung la rkyen dang bral na ni 'gag ste rang dbang med pas na mi rtag pa zhes bya /
analyzed: rkyen tshogs na ni 'byung la rkyen dang bral na ni 'gag ste rang dbang med pas na mi rtag pa zhes bya /
translated: When the conditions come together, it arises, and when it is separated from the conditions, it ceases. Since it is not independent, it is called “impermanent.”

original: du:kha zhes bya ba don du na pi d'artha ka tv'ad ces 'byung ste /
analyzed: du:kha zhes bya ba don du na pi d'artha ka tv'ad ces 'byung ste /
translated: The syllable du is in fact pidarthakata, which means “suffering.”

original: gnod pa'i phyir sdug bsngal ba zhes bya ste /🔽sh'u n+ya zhes bya ba /
analyzed: gnod pa'i phyir sdug bsngal ba zhes bya ste / sh'u n+ya zhes bya ba /
translated: It is called “suffering” because it is harmful.

original: a'atmi ya drishti bi paksha zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: a'atmi ya drishti bi paksha zhes 'byung ste /
translated: The syllable shunya is in fact atmiyadrishtibhiksha.

original: bdag gir lta ba'i gnyen po yin te /🔽bdag gi med cing stong pas na stong pa zhes bya /
analyzed: bdag gir lta ba'i gnyen po yin te / bdag gi med cing stong pas na stong pa zhes bya /
translated: It is the antidote to the view of “mine.”🔽Since it is empty and has no “mine,” it is called “empty.”

original: aa n'atma zhes bya ba a'atma zhes bya ba a'atma drishti bi bakshe aa n'atma zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: aa n'atma zhes bya ba a'atma zhes bya ba a'atma drishti bi bakshe aa n'atma zhes 'byung ste /
translated: The syllable a is in fact atma, which means “self.”

original: bdag tu lta ba'i gnyen po yin te /
analyzed: bdag tu lta ba'i gnyen po yin te /
translated: It is the antidote to the view of self.

original: mu stegs can gyis brtags pa'i bdag dang sems can la sogs pa med pas bdag med pa zhes bya /
analyzed: mu stegs can gyis brtags pa'i bdag dang sems can la sogs pa med pas bdag med pa zhes bya /
translated: It is called selflessness because it is devoid of the self and sentient beings imputed by tīrthikas.

original: he tu zhes bya ba he tu b'i dza dharmma yo ge na zhes 'byung bas sa bon gyi chos kyi tshul gyis phung po lnga'i rgyur gyur pas na rgyu zhes bya /
analyzed: he tu zhes bya ba he tu b'i dza dharmma yo ge na zhes 'byung bas sa bon gyi chos kyi tshul gyis phung po lnga'i rgyur gyur pas na rgyu zhes bya /
translated: Hetu means cause because it is the cause of the five aggregates by the method of the seed.

original: sa mu da ya zhes bya ba pra durba yo ge na zhes 'byung bas 'byung ba'i tshul gyis kun 'byung ba zhes bya /🔽pra bha ba zhes bya ba sam bandha yo ge na zhes 'byung ste /🔽'brel pa'i tshul gyis rgyu yin no zhes 'byung bas rgyu dang 'bras bu 'brel par skye ba'i phyir rab tu skye ba zhes bya /
analyzed: sa mu da ya zhes bya ba pra durba yo ge na zhes 'byung bas 'byung ba'i tshul gyis kun 'byung ba zhes bya / pra bha ba zhes bya ba sam bandha yo ge na zhes 'byung ste / 'brel pa'i tshul gyis rgyu yin no zhes 'byung bas rgyu dang 'bras bu 'brel par skye ba'i phyir rab tu skye ba zhes bya /
translated: Samudaya means origin because it is origin by the method of arising.🔽Prabhava means origination because it is the cause by the method of connection.

original: pra tya ya zhes bya ba aa bhi ni sh'a dha ni tyarthe na pra tya ya zhes 'byung bas mngon par grub par byed pa'i don gyis rkyen zhes bya ste /
analyzed: pra tya ya zhes bya ba aa bhi ni sh'a dha ni tyarthe na pra tya ya zhes 'byung bas mngon par grub par byed pa'i don gyis rkyen zhes bya ste /
translated: Pratyaya means condition because it is the cause by the method of connection.

original: dper na 'ji ba dang dbyu gu dang 'khor lo dang srad bu dang chu rnams tshogs pa las bum par 'grub par 'gyur ba dang 'dra bas na rkyen zhes bya /🔽ni ro dha zhes bya ba ni ro dha skandha pa ra ma ni ro dha zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: dper na 'ji ba dang dbyu gu dang 'khor lo dang srad bu dang chu rnams tshogs pa las bum par 'grub par 'gyur ba dang 'dra bas na rkyen zhes bya / ni ro dha zhes bya ba ni ro dha skandha pa ra ma ni ro dha zhes 'byung ste /
translated: For example, it is called a condition because it is like a pot being produced from the assembly of clay, a wheel, a stick, a rope, and water.

original: phung po 'jig cing med par 'gyur bas na 'gog @149b pa zhes bya /🔽sh'anta zhes bya ba tryagni nirbb'a n'ad sh'anta zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: phung po 'jig cing med par 'gyur bas na 'gog @149b pa zhes bya / sh'anta zhes bya ba tryagni nirbb'a n'ad sh'anta zhes 'byung ste /
translated: Nirodha means the aggregates are destroyed and become nonexistent, so it is called cessation.

original: 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug gi me rnam pa gsum med par byas pas na zhe ba zhes bya /
analyzed: 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug gi me rnam pa gsum med par byas pas na zhe ba zhes bya /
translated: Śānta means the three fires of attachment, aversion, and confusion are extinguished, so it is called peace.

original: pra ni ta zhes bya ba ni r'u ba dra b'ad tv'an zhes 'byung bas gnod pa med pa'i gya nom pa zhes bya /
analyzed: pra ni ta zhes bya ba ni r'u ba dra b'ad tv'an zhes 'byung bas gnod pa med pa'i gya nom pa zhes bya /
translated: Praṇīta means it is excellent without harm, as it says in the text.

original: nissa ra na zhes bya ba sarba aa baksha la bi yukta tv'ada nissa ra na zhes 'byung bas skyon thams cad dang bral te skyon rnams las byung ba 'am /
analyzed: nissa ra na zhes bya ba sarba aa baksha la bi yukta tv'ada nissa ra na zhes 'byung bas skyon thams cad dang bral te skyon rnams las byung ba 'am /
translated: Niḥsaraṇa means it is free from all faults and arises from the faults, as it says in the text.

original: bral bas na nges par 'byung ba zhes bya /
analyzed: bral bas na nges par 'byung ba zhes bya /
translated: It is called definite emergence because it is free from the obscurations of affliction and knowledge.

original: m'argga zhes bya ba ga ma n'a rthen m'argga zhes 'byung bas 'gro ba'i don la bya ste /
analyzed: m'argga zhes bya ba ga ma n'a rthen m'argga zhes 'byung bas 'gro ba'i don la bya ste /
translated: The Sanskrit word marga means path because it occurs in the statement gamana-artham marga iti, meaning it is for the purpose of going.

original: 'phags pa'i lam du zhugs nas mya ngan las 'das par 'gro ba'i don gyis lam zhes bya /
analyzed: 'phags pa'i lam du zhugs nas mya ngan las 'das par 'gro ba'i don gyis lam zhes bya /
translated: It is called a path because it is the path to nirvana for those who have entered the arya path.

original: n+y'a ya zhes bya ba yo ge yukta tv'ada n+y'a ya zhes 'byung bas rigs pa dang ldan par bshad pas lam de 'khrul pa med cing tshad mar gyur pas na rigs pa zhes bya /🔽pra ti patta zhes pa samyakbra ti pa da n'arthe na pra ti patta zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: n+y'a ya zhes bya ba yo ge yukta tv'ada n+y'a ya zhes 'byung bas rigs pa dang ldan par bshad pas lam de 'khrul pa med cing tshad mar gyur pas na rigs pa zhes bya / pra ti patta zhes pa samyakbra ti pa da n'arthe na pra ti patta zhes 'byung ste /
translated: The Sanskrit word nyaya means logic because it occurs in the statement yogye yuktatvad nyay iti, meaning it is logic because it is suitable and correct.

original: yang dag par thob par byed don gyis sgrub pa zhes bya /🔽niry'a ni ka zhes bya ba aatyanta sa ma ti kra m'a da niry'a ni ka zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: yang dag par thob par byed don gyis sgrub pa zhes bya / niry'a ni ka zhes bya ba aatyanta sa ma ti kra m'a da niry'a ni ka zhes 'byung ste /
translated: The Sanskrit word pratipat means practice because it occurs in the statement samyak-pratipadanarthena pratipat iti, meaning it is practice because it is the practice of the correct path.

original: shin tu yang dag par byung bas slar 'khor bar mi skye ba'i phyir nges par 'byin pa zhes bya /
analyzed: shin tu yang dag par byung bas slar 'khor bar mi skye ba'i phyir nges par 'byin pa zhes bya /
translated: The Sanskrit word niryana means definite emergence because it occurs in the statement atyanta-samattikramadananiryana iti, meaning it is definite emergence because it is the definite emergence of the ultimate.

original: aa nanta rya m'argga zhes bya ba /🔽aa nanta rya ni kle shee ranta ri du na sh'akya tv'ad ces bya ste /
analyzed: aa nanta rya m'argga zhes bya ba / aa nanta rya ni kle shee ranta ri du na sh'akya tv'ad ces bya ste /
translated: The path of no obstacles.

original: nyon mongs pas bar chad mi nus pas na bar chad med pa zhes bya /
analyzed: nyon mongs pas bar chad mi nus pas na bar chad med pa zhes bya /
translated: Anantarya means that the afflictions are not able to create an obstacle.

original: m'argga ni lam ste spyir na sgom pa'i lam la gnas pa'i tshe bzod pa nyon mongs pa'i gnyen por gyur pas na nyon mongs pa chom rkun dang 'dra ba sgor phyung zhing spangs pa la bya bas na bar chad med pa'i lam zhes btags /
analyzed: m'argga ni lam ste spyir na sgom pa'i lam la gnas pa'i tshe bzod pa nyon mongs pa'i gnyen por gyur pas na nyon mongs pa chom rkun dang 'dra ba sgor phyung zhing spangs pa la bya bas na bar chad med pa'i lam zhes btags /
translated: Marga means path. In general, when one is abiding on the path of meditation, since patience acts as the antidote to the afflictions, the afflictions are like thieves who have been expelled and abandoned at the door. Therefore, it is called the path of no obstacles.

original: bi mukta m'argga zhes bya ba bi mukta ni rnam par grol ba /
analyzed: bi mukta m'argga zhes bya ba bi mukta ni rnam par grol ba /
translated: The path of liberation. Vimukta means liberation.

original: m'argga ni lam ste sgom pa'i lam la nyon mongs pa dang bral ba'i shes pas rkun po slar mi 'ong bar sgo bcad pa lta bu yin te /
analyzed: m'argga ni lam ste sgom pa'i lam la nyon mongs pa dang bral ba'i shes pas rkun po slar mi 'ong bar sgo bcad pa lta bu yin te /
translated: Marga means path. On the path of meditation, since the consciousness that is free from the afflictions is like a door that has been closed so that the thieves cannot return,

original: rnam par grol ba'i lam zhes bya /🔽aa bhi sa ma y'anti ka ku sha la m'u la zhes bya ba mthong ba'i lam thob ste /
analyzed: rnam par grol ba'i lam zhes bya /🔽aa bhi sa ma y'anti ka ku sha la m'u la zhes bya ba mthong ba'i lam thob ste /
translated: it is called the path of liberation.🔽The path of complete training. Abhisamaya means complete training.

original: de kho na nyid rtogs pa'i rjes la 'jig rten pa'i dge ba mang po 'phel zhing 'byung ba'i ming ste /
analyzed: de kho na nyid rtogs pa'i rjes la 'jig rten pa'i dge ba mang po 'phel zhing 'byung ba'i ming ste /
translated: It is the name of the many mundane virtues that increase and arise after the realization of thatness.

original: mngon par rtogs pa'i mjug la 'byung ba'i dge ba'i rtsa ba zhes bya /
analyzed: mngon par rtogs pa'i mjug la 'byung ba'i dge ba'i rtsa ba zhes bya /
translated: It is called the roots of virtue that arise after the realization of the truth.

original: ksha ya dzny'a na bi ka ku sha la m'u la zhes bya ba /
analyzed: ksha ya dzny'a na bi ka ku sha la m'u la zhes bya ba /
translated: Kṣayajñāna, vaika, kuśala, mūla

original: dgra bcom pa'i zad pa shes ba skyes pa'i 'phral la 'jig rten pa'i dge ba mang po skyes pa'i ming ste /
analyzed: dgra bcom pa'i zad pa shes ba skyes pa'i 'phral la 'jig rten pa'i dge ba mang po skyes pa'i ming ste /
translated: It is the name of the many mundane virtues that arise immediately after the arhat's knowledge of the exhaustion of defilements.

original: zad pa shes pas thob pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba zhes bya /
analyzed: zad pa shes pas thob pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba zhes bya /
translated: It is called the roots of virtue obtained through the knowledge of exhaustion.

original: sems kyi skad cig bcu drug la du:khe dharmma dzny'a na ksh'anti zhes bya ba du:khe ni @150a * //
analyzed: sems kyi skad cig bcu drug la du:khe dharmma dzny'a na ksh'anti zhes bya ba du:khe ni @150a * //
translated: The sixteen moments of mind are called duḥkhe dharmajñānakṣānti.🔽Duḥkha is suffering.

original: sdug bsngal / dharmma ni chos /
analyzed: sdug bsngal / dharmma ni chos /
translated: Dharma is reality.

original: dzny'a na ni shes pa /
analyzed: dzny'a na ni shes pa /
translated: Jñāna is knowledge.

original: ksh'anti ni bzod pa ste /🔽sdug bsngal la chos de kho na nyid rtogs par bya bar bzod pas na shes rab kyi ming ste /
analyzed: ksh'anti ni bzod pa ste / sdug bsngal la chos de kho na nyid rtogs par bya bar bzod pas na shes rab kyi ming ste /
translated: Kṣānti is patience.🔽It is the name of the wisdom that is patient with the suffering that is the reality of thatness.

original: sdug bsngal la chos shes pa'i bzod pa zhes bya /
analyzed: sdug bsngal la chos shes pa'i bzod pa zhes bya /
translated: It is called the patience that is the knowledge of the reality of suffering.

original: du:khedharmma dzny'a na zhes bya ba chos shes pa'i bzod pa'i rjes la sdug bsngal gyi chos de kho na nyid rtogs par 'gyur bas na sdug bsngal la chos shes pa zhes bya /🔽du:khe nva ya ksh'anti zhes bya ba du:khe bi sha ye aa nu pashtsad aa ya aa ba ga ma zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: du:khedharmma dzny'a na zhes bya ba chos shes pa'i bzod pa'i rjes la sdug bsngal gyi chos de kho na nyid rtogs par 'gyur bas na sdug bsngal la chos shes pa zhes bya / du:khe nva ya ksh'anti zhes bya ba du:khe bi sha ye aa nu pashtsad aa ya aa ba ga ma zhes 'byung ste /
translated: The one called duḥkhe’nvayajñānakṣānti is the forbearance of the subsequent knowledge of suffering.

original: ji ltar 'dod pa'i khams kyi sdug bsngal la chos shes par bzod pa de bzhin du gzugs dang gzugs med pa'i khams kyi chos shes pa la bzod pas na sdug bsngal la rjes su rtogs pa'i shes pa zhes bya ste /
analyzed: ji ltar 'dod pa'i khams kyi sdug bsngal la chos shes par bzod pa de bzhin du gzugs dang gzugs med pa'i khams kyi chos shes pa la bzod pas na sdug bsngal la rjes su rtogs pa'i shes pa zhes bya ste /
translated: Just as one forbears the dharma knowledge of the suffering of the desire realm, so one forbears the dharma knowledge of the suffering of the form and formless realms.

original: chos shes pa ni 'dod pa'i khams la dmigs te /
analyzed: chos shes pa ni 'dod pa'i khams la dmigs te /
translated: Dharma knowledge focuses on the desire realm,

original: sa la lta ba dang 'dra la /
analyzed: sa la lta ba dang 'dra la /
translated: like looking at the ground.

original: rjes su rtogs pa'i shes pa ni gzugs dang gzugs med pa'i nyon mongs pa'i gnyen po ste /
analyzed: rjes su rtogs pa'i shes pa ni gzugs dang gzugs med pa'i nyon mongs pa'i gnyen po ste /
translated: Subsequent knowledge is the antidote to the afflictions of the form and formless realms,🔽like looking at the sky.

original: gnam la yar lta ba dang 'dra bas chos shes pa dang rjes su rtogs pa'i shes pa gnyis gcig gi yul gcig gis mi mthong /
analyzed: gnam la yar lta ba dang 'dra bas chos shes pa dang rjes su rtogs pa'i shes pa gnyis gcig gi yul gcig gis mi mthong /
translated: Since it is like looking up at the sky, the two knowledges of knowing phenomena and subsequent knowledge do not see the same object.

original: kun 'byung ba man chad lhag ma gsum yang 'di bzhin bshad /
analyzed: kun 'byung ba man chad lhag ma gsum yang 'di bzhin bshad /
translated: The remaining three are explained in the same way as the truth of origin.

original: mi shes pa kun shes par byed pa la sogs pa dbang po gsum la /
analyzed: mi shes pa kun shes par byed pa la sogs pa dbang po gsum la /
translated: With regard to the three faculties such as producing complete knowledge of the unknown,

original: aa n'a dzny'a ta m'a dzny'a t'a sya mindri yan zhes bya ba mi shes pa kun shes par byed pa'i dbang po yin te /
analyzed: aa n'a dzny'a ta m'a dzny'a t'a sya mindri yan zhes bya ba mi shes pa kun shes par byed pa'i dbang po yin te /
translated: the line anajnatam ajnanasyendriyaman says:🔽The faculty producing complete knowledge of the unknown is the mental faculty of the path of seeing, the faculties of pleasure, mental satisfaction, equanimity, faith, effort, mindfulness, concentration and wisdom.

original: mthong ba'i lam gyi yid dang / bde ba dang / yid bde ba dang / btang snyoms dang / dad pa dang / brtson 'grus dang / dran pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / shes rab kyi dbang po rnams sngon 'phags pa'i bden pa ma mthong ba mthong bar byed pa kun shes pa'i dbang po mthong ba la dbang byed pas na mi shes pa kun shes par byed pa'i dbang po zhes bya /
analyzed: mthong ba'i lam gyi yid dang / bde ba dang / yid bde ba dang / btang snyoms dang / dad pa dang / brtson 'grus dang / dran pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / shes rab kyi dbang po rnams sngon 'phags pa'i bden pa ma mthong ba mthong bar byed pa kun shes pa'i dbang po mthong ba la dbang byed pas na mi shes pa kun shes par byed pa'i dbang po zhes bya /
translated: Since it controls the seeing of the arya truths not previously seen, it is called the faculty producing complete knowledge of the unknown.

original: a'a dzny'e ndri yan zhes bya ba kun shes pa'i dbang po yin te /
analyzed: a'a dzny'e ndri yan zhes bya ba kun shes pa'i dbang po yin te /
translated: The faculty of complete knowledge is ajnanendriya.

original: sgom pa'i lam la kun shes par bya ba'i yul gzhan med kyi /
analyzed: sgom pa'i lam la kun shes par bya ba'i yul gzhan med kyi /
translated: On the path of meditation, there is no other object to be completely known,

original: bag la nyal lhag ma spang ba'i phyir sgom pa'i lam gyi yid la sogs pa'i dbang po dgus 'phags pa'i lam gyi bden pa de nyid kun shes pa yin te /
analyzed: bag la nyal lhag ma spang ba'i phyir sgom pa'i lam gyi yid la sogs pa'i dbang po dgus 'phags pa'i lam gyi bden pa de nyid kun shes pa yin te /
translated: but in order to abandon remaining latent states, the nine faculties such as the mental faculty of the path of meditation completely know that truth of the arya path.

original: kun shes pa dang ldan pa'i dbang po thob pa la dbang byed pas na kun shes pa'i dbang po zhes bya /
analyzed: kun shes pa dang ldan pa'i dbang po thob pa la dbang byed pas na kun shes pa'i dbang po zhes bya /
translated: It is called the faculty of complete knowledge because it controls the obtainment of the faculty possessing complete knowledge.

original: a'a dzny'a t'i yindri yan zhes bya ba kun shes pa dang ldan pa'i dbang po yin te /
analyzed: a'a dzny'a t'i yindri yan zhes bya ba kun shes pa dang ldan pa'i dbang po yin te /
translated: The faculty possessing complete knowledge is ajnatavindriya.

original: mi slob pa'i lam la dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu thob nas @150b shes par bya ba thams cad shes te /
analyzed: mi slob pa'i lam la dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu thob nas @150b shes par bya ba thams cad shes te /
translated: On the path of no learning, having obtained the result of arhat, all that is to be known is known.

original: shes pa de dang ldan pas gang gi sems kyi rgyud la yod pa'i yid la sogs pa'i dbang po dgu tshe 'di la bde bar gnas pa dang mya ngan 'das pa thob par byed pas na kun shes pa dang ldan pa'i dbang po zhes bya /
analyzed: shes pa de dang ldan pas gang gi sems kyi rgyud la yod pa'i yid la sogs pa'i dbang po dgu tshe 'di la bde bar gnas pa dang mya ngan 'das pa thob par byed pas na kun shes pa dang ldan pa'i dbang po zhes bya /
translated: Since one possesses that knowledge, the nine faculties such as the mental faculty that exist in one's mindstream are called the faculty possessing complete knowledge because they cause one to abide in bliss in this life and attain nirvana.

original: lam bzhi la /
analyzed: lam bzhi la /
translated: The four paths

original: du:kha pra ti paddhya na dhy'a bhi dzny'a zhes bya ba bsam gtan bzhi'i sa la ma gtogs pa gzugs med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa lta bu lhag mthong med la zhi gnas kyi shas che ba dang / mi lcogs pa med pa bsam gtan dang po la 'jug pa'i sems lta bu lhag mthong gi shas che la zhi gnas dang lhag mthong ya char gyur pas nyon mongs pa spang dka' la gang zag dbang po rtul po'i shes pa'i ming ste /
analyzed: du:kha pra ti paddhya na dhy'a bhi dzny'a zhes bya ba bsam gtan bzhi'i sa la ma gtogs pa gzugs med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa lta bu lhag mthong med la zhi gnas kyi shas che ba dang / mi lcogs pa med pa bsam gtan dang po la 'jug pa'i sems lta bu lhag mthong gi shas che la zhi gnas dang lhag mthong ya char gyur pas nyon mongs pa spang dka' la gang zag dbang po rtul po'i shes pa'i ming ste /
translated: The path that is difficult and slow is the name of the consciousness of a person of dull faculty, such as the formless meditative attainment that is not included in the levels of the four concentrations, which lacks insight and has a predominance of calm abiding, or the mind that enters the first concentration without difficulty, which has a predominance of insight and is a combination of calm abiding and insight, making it difficult to abandon afflictions.

original: mngon par shes pa bul la dka' ba'i lam zhes bya /
analyzed: mngon par shes pa bul la dka' ba'i lam zhes bya /
translated: It is called the path that is difficult and slow to higher perception.

original: du:kha pra ti pa takshi pr'a bhi dzny'a zhes bya ba bsam gtan bzhi las ma gtogs pa gzugs med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa lta bu lhag mthong med la zhi gnas kyi shas che ba dang / mi lcogs pa med pa bsam gtan dang po la 'jug pa'i sems lta bu lhag mthong gi shas che ba la zhi gnas chung ste /
analyzed: du:kha pra ti pa takshi pr'a bhi dzny'a zhes bya ba bsam gtan bzhi las ma gtogs pa gzugs med pa'i snyoms par 'jug pa lta bu lhag mthong med la zhi gnas kyi shas che ba dang / mi lcogs pa med pa bsam gtan dang po la 'jug pa'i sems lta bu lhag mthong gi shas che ba la zhi gnas chung ste /
translated: The fourth is called the “application of the two together” and is the union of calm abiding and insight.🔽🔽The fifth is called “the application of the two in alternation.” This is the practice of calm abiding and insight in a sequence.🔽🔽The sixth is called “the application of the two in combination.” This is the practice of calm abiding and insight in a single sitting.🔽🔽The seventh is called “the application of the two in a single mental act.” This is the practice of calm abiding and insight in a single mental act.🔽🔽The eighth is called “the application of the two in a single nature.” This is the practice of calm abiding and insight in a single nature.🔽🔽The ninth is called “the application of the two in a single support.” This is the practice of calm abiding and insight in a single support.🔽🔽The tenth is called “the application of the two in a single moment.” This is the practice of calm abiding and insight in a single moment.🔽🔽The eleventh is called “the application of the two in a single essence.” This is the practice of calm abiding and insight in a single essence.🔽🔽The twelfth is called “the application of the two in a single attainment.” This is the practice of calm abiding and insight in a single attainment.🔽🔽The thirteenth is called “the application of the two in a single non-attainment.” This is the practice of calm abiding and insight in a single non-attainment.🔽🔽The fourteenth is called “the application of the two in a single non-observation.” This is the practice of calm abiding and insight in a single non-observation.🔽

original: zhi gnas dang lhag mthong ya char gyur pas nyon mongs pa spang dka' la /🔽gang zag dbang po rnon po'i shes pa'i ming ste /
analyzed: zhi gnas dang lhag mthong ya char gyur pas nyon mongs pa spang dka' la / gang zag dbang po rnon po'i shes pa'i ming ste /
translated: The path of difficulty and slow higher perception is called duḥkha-pratipad-dhandhābhijñā.🔽The path of ease and slow higher perception is called sukha-pratipad-dhandhābhijñā.

original: mngon par shes pa myur la dka' ba'i lam zhes bya /
analyzed: mngon par shes pa myur la dka' ba'i lam zhes bya /
translated: The path of difficulty and quick higher perception is called duḥkha-pratipad-kṣiprābhijñā.🔽The path of ease and quick higher perception is called sukha-pratipad-kṣiprābhijñā.

original: su kh'a pra ti paddhya na dhy'a bhi dzny'a zhes bya ba bsam gtan bzhi'i sa la zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zung du 'brel pa bsgoms pas nyon mongs pa spang zhing bsal sla la /🔽gang zag dbang po rtul po'i shes pa'i ming ste /
analyzed: su kh'a pra ti paddhya na dhy'a bhi dzny'a zhes bya ba bsam gtan bzhi'i sa la zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zung du 'brel pa bsgoms pas nyon mongs pa spang zhing bsal sla la /🔽gang zag dbang po rtul po'i shes pa'i ming ste /
translated: The path of difficulty and slow higher perception is called duḥkha-pratipad-dhandhābhijñā.🔽The path of ease and slow higher perception is called sukha-pratipad-dhandhābhijñā.🔽The path of difficulty and quick higher perception is called duḥkha-pratipad-kṣiprābhijñā.🔽The path of ease and quick higher perception is called sukha-pratipad-kṣiprābhijñā.

original: mngon par shes pa bul la sla ba'i lam zhes bya ;🔽su kha pra ti pa ta kshi pr'a bhi dzny'a zhes pa bsam gtan bzhi pa'i sa la zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zung du 'brel pa bsgoms pas nyon mongs pa spang zhing bsal sla la /🔽gang zag dbang po rnon po'i shes pa'i ming ste /
analyzed: mngon par shes pa bul la sla ba'i lam zhes bya ; su kha pra ti pa ta kshi pr'a bhi dzny'a zhes pa bsam gtan bzhi pa'i sa la zhi gnas dang lhag mthong zung du 'brel pa bsgoms pas nyon mongs pa spang zhing bsal sla la / gang zag dbang po rnon po'i shes pa'i ming ste /
translated: The path of the one who is quick in higher perception is called the path of the one who is quick in higher perception.🔽The path that is slow and easy is called the path of the one who is slow and easy in higher perception.🔽The path that is quick and easy is called the path of the one who is quick and easy in higher perception.

original: mngon par shes pa myur la sla ba'i lam zhes bya /🔽kun rdzob dang don dam pa'i bden pa la sam bri ti sa tya zhes bya ba sam bri ya te aa na ya tvatta zhes bya ste /
analyzed: mngon par shes pa myur la sla ba'i lam zhes bya / kun rdzob dang don dam pa'i bden pa la sam bri ti sa tya zhes bya ba sam bri ya te aa na ya tvatta zhes bya ste /
translated: The path that is slow and difficult is called the path of the one who is slow and difficult in higher perception.🔽The path of the one who is slow in higher perception is called the path of the one who is slow in higher perception.

original: rnam par rtog pa dang bcas pa'i shes pas dngos po'i de kho na nyid mthong bar bya ba la sgrib pas na yang dag sgrib ces bya /🔽yang gcig tu na /
analyzed: rnam par rtog pa dang bcas pa'i shes pas dngos po'i de kho na nyid mthong bar bya ba la sgrib pas na yang dag sgrib ces bya / yang gcig tu na /
translated: The path of the one who is quick in higher perception is called the path of the one who is quick in higher perception.

original: lo ka sam bri ty'a satya zhes bya ste /🔽chos thams cad rang bzhin med cing stong @151a * //
analyzed: lo ka sam bri ty'a satya zhes bya ste /🔽chos thams cad rang bzhin med cing stong @151a * //
translated: The path that is slow and easy is called the path of the one who is slow and easy in higher perception.🔽The path that is quick and easy is called the path of the one who is quick and easy in higher perception.🔽The path that is slow and difficult is called the path of the one who is slow and difficult in higher perception.🔽The path of the one who is slow in higher perception is called the path of the one who is

original: pa las 'jig rten gyi phyin ci log gi dngos po skye zhing 'byung bar mthong ba la sogs pa 'ang 'jig rten gyi tha snyad dang grags pa tsam du bden pa ste /
analyzed: pa las 'jig rten gyi phyin ci log gi dngos po skye zhing 'byung bar mthong ba la sogs pa 'ang 'jig rten gyi tha snyad dang grags pa tsam du bden pa ste /
translated: The arising and occurrence of things that are erroneous in the world are also true in the sense of being merely the conventions and renown of the world.

original: kun gyis shes shing rdzob pa la bya bar dbu ma'i gtsug lag las bshad /
analyzed: kun gyis shes shing rdzob pa la bya bar dbu ma'i gtsug lag las bshad /
translated: The treatises of the Middle Way explain that they are to be understood by all and are called “the conventional.”

original: blo gros mi zad pas bstan pa la sogs pa'i nang nas ji snyed du yi ge dang tshig 'brus bstan pa thams cad ni kun rdzob kyi bden pa'o zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: blo gros mi zad pas bstan pa la sogs pa'i nang nas ji snyed du yi ge dang tshig 'brus bstan pa thams cad ni kun rdzob kyi bden pa'o zhes 'byung ste /
translated: The Akṣayamatisūtra and so on state, “All that is taught by means of letters and words is the conventional truth.”

original: mdo sde dang dbu ma'i gzhung btsan par bya ste /
analyzed: mdo sde dang dbu ma'i gzhung btsan par bya ste /
translated: The sūtras and the treatises of the Middle Way are to be taken as authoritative.

original: kun rdzob kyi bden par btags /
analyzed: kun rdzob kyi bden par btags /
translated: They designate the conventional truth.🔽  The term paramārtha is a compound of parama and artha.

original: pa ra m'artha zhes bya ba par ma ni mchog gam dam pa /
analyzed: pa ra m'artha zhes bya ba par ma ni mchog gam dam pa /
translated: Parama means supreme or holy.

original: aartha ni don nam dgos pa ste /
analyzed: aartha ni don nam dgos pa ste /
translated: Artha means purpose or goal.

original: gcig tu don sgrub cing dgos pa bya ba'i mchog tu sdug bsngal thams cad dang bral bar bya ba mya ngan las 'das pa la yang bya /
analyzed: gcig tu don sgrub cing dgos pa bya ba'i mchog tu sdug bsngal thams cad dang bral bar bya ba mya ngan las 'das pa la yang bya /
translated: It is used for nirvana, which is the supreme purpose or goal that is accomplished in a single way, the freedom from all suffering.

original: yang gcig tu na /
analyzed: yang gcig tu na /
translated: In another way,

original: 'jig rten las 'das pa'i ye shes mchog gi dmigs pa'i spyod yul lam don du gyur pa yin la /
analyzed: 'jig rten las 'das pa'i ye shes mchog gi dmigs pa'i spyod yul lam don du gyur pa yin la /
translated: It is the domain or object of the supreme supramundane wisdom.

original: satya ni bden pa ste /
analyzed: satya ni bden pa ste /
translated: Satya means truth.

original: 'phags pa phyin ci log med par gzigs pa rnams la mya ngan las 'das pa dang skye ba med par yang dag par bden pas na don dam pa'i bden pa zhes bya /
analyzed: 'phags pa phyin ci log med par gzigs pa rnams la mya ngan las 'das pa dang skye ba med par yang dag par bden pas na don dam pa'i bden pa zhes bya /
translated: Since nirvana and nonarising are perfectly true for the noble ones who see without error, it is called ultimate truth.

original: lung du bstan pa'i rnam grangs kyi ming la /🔽ae k'am sha by'a ka ra na zhes bya ba sems can thams cad 'chi 'am mi 'chi zhes 'dri na /
analyzed: lung du bstan pa'i rnam grangs kyi ming la / ae k'am sha by'a ka ra na zhes bya ba sems can thams cad 'chi 'am mi 'chi zhes 'dri na /
translated: Names of the Enumerations of the Scriptures🔽Ekaṃ śabda-vyākaraṇa means if one asks, “Do all sentient beings die or not?”

original: gcig tu chad par thams cad 'chi'o zhes bya ba yin te /
analyzed: gcig tu chad par thams cad 'chi'o zhes bya ba yin te /
translated: It is a definitive answer that all do die.

original: mgo gcig tu lung bstan pa zhes bya /
analyzed: mgo gcig tu lung bstan pa zhes bya /
translated: It is called a definitive answer.

original: bi bha dza by'a ka ra na zhes bya ba sems can thams cad skye 'am zhes 'dri na /
analyzed: bi bha dza by'a ka ra na zhes bya ba sems can thams cad skye 'am zhes 'dri na /
translated: Vibhajyā-vyākaraṇa means if one asks, “Are all sentient beings born?”

original: nyon mongs pa dang bcas pa ni skye la /
analyzed: nyon mongs pa dang bcas pa ni skye la /
translated: Those with afflictions are born.

original: nyon mongs pa med pa ni mi skye'o zhes so sor phye ste bstan par bya ba'i ming ste rnam par phye ste lung bstan pa zhes bya /
analyzed: nyon mongs pa med pa ni mi skye'o zhes so sor phye ste bstan par bya ba'i ming ste rnam par phye ste lung bstan pa zhes bya /
translated: The name of the one to be taught is taught by distinguishing it, as in “The one without afflictions does not arise.”

original: pa ri britstsha by'a ka ra na zhes bya ba mi 'di bzang ngam ngan zhes 'dri na /
analyzed: pa ri britstsha by'a ka ra na zhes bya ba mi 'di bzang ngam ngan zhes 'dri na /
translated: Paripṛcchāvyākaraṇa means that if one asks, “Is this person good or bad?”

original: gang dang gang sgrun zhes slar dri ste /
analyzed: gang dang gang sgrun zhes slar dri ste /
translated: one is asked in return, “Compared to what?”

original: lha dang sgrun zhes zer na ni ngan zhes bya /
analyzed: lha dang sgrun zhes zer na ni ngan zhes bya /
translated: If one says, “Compared to a god,” one is told, “He is bad.”

original: sems can dmyal ba dang sgrun zhes zer na ni bzang zhes bya ba lta bu /
analyzed: sems can dmyal ba dang sgrun zhes zer na ni bzang zhes bya ba lta bu /
translated: If one says, “Compared to a hell being,” one is told, “He is good.”

original: slar dris nas lan blan pa'i ming ste dris nas lung bstan pa zhes bya /
analyzed: slar dris nas lan blan pa'i ming ste dris nas lung bstan pa zhes bya /
translated: The name of the one to be taught is taught by asking a question in return.

original: sth'i tya by'a ka ra na zhes bya ba sems can dang phung po gnyis gcig gam tha dad ces 'dri na /
analyzed: sth'i tya by'a ka ra na zhes bya ba sems can dang phung po gnyis gcig gam tha dad ces 'dri na /
translated: Sthityavyākaraṇa means that if one asks, “Are sentient beings and the aggregates the same or different?”

original: sems nyid dngos por med pas mo gsham gyi bu dkar ram sngo zhes brjod du med pa dang 'dra ste /
analyzed: sems nyid dngos por med pas mo gsham gyi bu dkar ram sngo zhes brjod du med pa dang 'dra ste /
translated: since the mind itself is not a thing, it is like saying, “Is the son of a barren woman white or blue?”

original: lung mi bstan pas na gzhag pa'i lung bstan pa zhes bya /
analyzed: lung mi bstan pas na gzhag pa'i lung bstan pa zhes bya /
translated: Since it is not a matter of prediction, it is called a prediction of setting aside.

original: mtshan nyid gsum la pa ri kalpi ta laksha na zhes bya ba kun brtags pa'i @151b mtshan nyid yin te /
analyzed: mtshan nyid gsum la pa ri kalpi ta laksha na zhes bya ba kun brtags pa'i @151b mtshan nyid yin te /
translated: The imagined reality is called parikalpita-laksana.

original: pa ri sa mam t'ad ces bya ba yongs su 'am kun tu /
analyzed: pa ri sa mam t'ad ces bya ba yongs su 'am kun tu /
translated: Pari means “all” or “entirely,”

original: kalpi ta ni med pa 'am sgro btags pa lta bu la bya /
analyzed: kalpi ta ni med pa 'am sgro btags pa lta bu la bya /
translated: kalpita means “nonexistent” or “imaginary.”

original: spyir na gzung ba dang 'dzin par bcas pa'i chos nan gyis brtags pa la bya ste /
analyzed: spyir na gzung ba dang 'dzin par bcas pa'i chos nan gyis brtags pa la bya ste /
translated: In general, it refers to the imputation of phenomena as subject and object.

original: kun brtags pa'i mtshan nyid ces bya /
analyzed: kun brtags pa'i mtshan nyid ces bya /
translated: This is called the imagined reality.

original: pa ra tantra laksha na zhes bya ba gzhan gyi dbang gi mtshan nyid yin te /
analyzed: pa ra tantra laksha na zhes bya ba gzhan gyi dbang gi mtshan nyid yin te /
translated: The dependent reality is called paratantra-laksana.

original: pa ra ni gzhan /
analyzed: pa ra ni gzhan /
translated: Para means “other,”

original: tantra ni tantra ste dzanmya te zhes bya ste /
analyzed: tantra ni tantra ste dzanmya te zhes bya ste /
translated: tantra means “arising” (tantrāḥ=jāmyate).

original: gzhan gyi rkyen la rag las shing rang mi 'byung bas rten cing 'brel pa 'byung ba'i ming ste /
analyzed: gzhan gyi rkyen la rag las shing rang mi 'byung bas rten cing 'brel pa 'byung ba'i ming ste /
translated: Since it arises in dependence on other conditions and does not arise by itself, it is called dependent arising.

original: gzhan gyi dbang gi mtshan nyid ces bya /
analyzed: gzhan gyi dbang gi mtshan nyid ces bya /
translated: This is called the dependent reality.

original: pa ri nishpanna laksha na zhes bya ba yongs su grub pa'i mtshan nyid yin te /
analyzed: pa ri nishpanna laksha na zhes bya ba yongs su grub pa'i mtshan nyid yin te /
translated: The fully present reality is called parinispanna-laksana.

original: de bzhin nyid dang / yang dag pa'i ye shes gnyis mi 'gyur ba dang / phyin ci ma log pa'i tshul gyis yongs su rdzogs shing grub pas na yongs su grub pa'i mtshan nyid ces bya /
analyzed: de bzhin nyid dang / yang dag pa'i ye shes gnyis mi 'gyur ba dang / phyin ci ma log pa'i tshul gyis yongs su rdzogs shing grub pas na yongs su grub pa'i mtshan nyid ces bya /
translated: The ultimate reality and the authentic pristine consciousness are completely perfect and accomplished in the manner of being unchanging and nonerroneous, so it is called the characteristic of the thoroughly established.

original: dgongs pa bzhi la /
analyzed: dgongs pa bzhi la /
translated: There are four intentions:

original: tsa tv'a ro aa bhi pr'a ya zhes pa dgongs pa bzhi yin te chos kyi sku dang / tshogs la sogs pa mnyam pa la dgongs te ;
analyzed: tsa tv'a ro aa bhi pr'a ya zhes pa dgongs pa bzhi yin te chos kyi sku dang / tshogs la sogs pa mnyam pa la dgongs te ;
translated: The four intentions are catvarabhiprāya.

original: 'das pa'i sangs rgyas kyang nga nyid yin zhes bka' stsal pa lta bu mnyam pa nyid la dgongs pa /
analyzed: 'das pa'i sangs rgyas kyang nga nyid yin zhes bka' stsal pa lta bu mnyam pa nyid la dgongs pa /
translated: The intention of sameness is, for example, the statement, “I am the buddha of the past.”🔽The intention of another time is, for example, ‘Those who hear the name of the tathāgata will fully awaken to unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.’

original: de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan thos pa tsam gyis bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya'o zhes bya ba lta bu dus gzhan la dgongs pa dang / sangs rgyas gangg'a'i klung gi bye ma snyed la bsnyen bkur byas na /
analyzed: de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan thos pa tsam gyis bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu mngon par rdzogs par 'tshang rgya'o zhes bya ba lta bu dus gzhan la dgongs pa dang / sangs rgyas gangg'a'i klung gi bye ma snyed la bsnyen bkur byas na /
translated: The intention of another meaning is, for example, ‘Those who serve as many buddhas as there are grains of sand in the Ganges river will attain buddhahood.’

original: gdod theg pa chen po'i don khong du chud do zhes bya ba lta bu don gzhan la dgongs pa dang / gang zag gcig la sngar sbyin pa la sogs pa'i legs pa brjod la phyis smad pa lta bu gang zag gi bsam pa la dgongs pa'i ming yin te dgongs pa bzhi zhes bya /
analyzed: gdod theg pa chen po'i don khong du chud do zhes bya ba lta bu don gzhan la dgongs pa dang / gang zag gcig la sngar sbyin pa la sogs pa'i legs pa brjod la phyis smad pa lta bu gang zag gi bsam pa la dgongs pa'i ming yin te dgongs pa bzhi zhes bya /
translated: The four kinds of implied teachings are implied teachings concerning another meaning, as in the statement, “I have understood the meaning of the Great Vehicle from the beginning,” implied teachings concerning another time, as in the statement, “If you recite the mantra of the kṣetrapāla, you will not be harmed by poison,” implied teachings concerning another text, as in the statement, “The Tathāgata has taught the Dharma of the three vehicles,” and implied teachings concerning the individual, as in the statement, “Previously I praised generosity and so on, but later I criticized them.”

original: ldem por dgongs pa bzhi la /
analyzed: ldem por dgongs pa bzhi la /
translated: The four kinds of indirect teachings are

original: tsa tv'a y'a bhi sandhi zhes bya ba ldem por dgongs pa bzhi yin te /
analyzed: tsa tv'a y'a bhi sandhi zhes bya ba ldem por dgongs pa bzhi yin te /
translated: the four kinds of indirect teachings, which are called catvāro ’bhisandhayaḥ.

original: sems can chos la drangs pa'i phyir theg pa chung ngu las bdag dang gang zag la sogs pa yod par bshad pa lta bu gzhug pa la ldem por dgongs pa dang / kun brtags pa dngos po med par bshad pa dang ; gzhan gyi dbang rten cing 'brel par bshad pa dang /
analyzed: sems can chos la drangs pa'i phyir theg pa chung ngu las bdag dang gang zag la sogs pa yod par bshad pa lta bu gzhug pa la ldem por dgongs pa dang / kun brtags pa dngos po med par bshad pa dang ; gzhan gyi dbang rten cing 'brel par bshad pa dang /
translated: They are indirect teachings concerning introduction, as in the statement in the Hinayana that the self, the individual, and so on exist, in order to introduce sentient beings to the Dharma; indirect teachings concerning the nonexistence of the imputed, as in the statement that the imputed nature does not exist; indirect teachings concerning the dependent being dependently arisen, as in the statement that the dependent nature is dependently arisen; and indirect teachings concerning the ultimate being the perfected, as in the statement that the perfected nature is the ultimate.

original: yongs su grub pa mi 'gyur ba dang phyin ci log par bshad pa lta bu mtshan nyid la ldem por dgongs pa dang / sems can gyi spyod pa brgyad khri bzhi stong gi gnyen por chos sna tshogs bshad pa lta bu gnyen po la ldem por dgongs pa dang /
analyzed: yongs su grub pa mi 'gyur ba dang phyin ci log par bshad pa lta bu mtshan nyid la ldem por dgongs pa dang / sems can gyi spyod pa brgyad khri bzhi stong gi gnyen por chos sna tshogs bshad pa lta bu gnyen po la ldem por dgongs pa dang /
translated: The four kinds of implied teachings are implied teachings concerning characteristics, such as the statements that the fully present reality is unchanging and that it is not erroneous; implied teachings concerning antidotes, such as the various teachings on the Dharma as an antidote to the eighty-four thousand negative emotions and habitual tendencies;

original: @152a * // nyon mongs pas gnas na byang chub kyi mchog thob po zhes 'byung ba lta bu byang chub kyi spyad pa dka' ba la dgongs te nyon mongs pa zhes gsungs pa la sogs pa bsgyur ba la ldem por dgongs pa dang 'di bzhi ldem bu bzhin du tshig thel
analyzed: @152a * // nyon mongs pas gnas na byang chub kyi mchog thob po zhes 'byung ba lta bu byang chub kyi spyad pa dka' ba la dgongs te nyon mongs pa zhes gsungs pa la sogs pa bsgyur ba la ldem por dgongs pa dang 'di bzhi ldem bu bzhin du tshig thel
translated: implied teachings concerning transformation, such as the statement that if one abides in defilement, one will attain supreme enlightenment.

original: gyis mi gdab par bsgyur te bstan pa yin pas ldem por dgongs pa bzhi zhes bya /
analyzed: gyis mi gdab par bsgyur te bstan pa yin pas ldem por dgongs pa bzhi zhes bya /
translated: The four kinds of implied teachings are like a springboard, for they are taught in order to transform the words and meanings of the four kinds of implied teachings without adding to them.

original: aa bhi pr'a ya dang ma 'dom na aa bhi sandhi yang dgongs par gdags /
analyzed: aa bhi pr'a ya dang ma 'dom na aa bhi sandhi yang dgongs par gdags /
translated: The Sanskrit abhiprāya is rendered in Tibetan as dgons pa, which is also the Tibetan for abhisandhi.

original: phung po dang khams dang skye mched la r'u pa skandha ni r'u pa ny'ad r'u pam zhes bya ste /
analyzed: phung po dang khams dang skye mched la r'u pa skandha ni r'u pa ny'ad r'u pam zhes bya ste /
translated: The aggregates, elements, and sense bases are called rūpa, skandha, and āyatana.

original: lag pa dang dbyig pa la sogs pas gzugs shing gnod par byar rung bas na gzugs zhes bya /
analyzed: lag pa dang dbyig pa la sogs pas gzugs shing gnod par byar rung bas na gzugs zhes bya /
translated: Rūpa means that which can be formed and harmed by hands, sticks, and so on.

original: skandha ni dus gsum gyi gzugs bzang ngan dang che phra yod do cog gcig tu bsdus pa'i ming ste gzugs kyi phung po zhes bya /
analyzed: skandha ni dus gsum gyi gzugs bzang ngan dang che phra yod do cog gcig tu bsdus pa'i ming ste gzugs kyi phung po zhes bya /
translated: Skandha is the name that includes all good and bad forms of the three times, large and small, in one place. It is called the form aggregate.

original: be da n'a skandha zhes bya ba ni aa nu bha ba laksha na be da na na ka mi ka zhes bya ba ste /
analyzed: be da n'a skandha zhes bya ba ni aa nu bha ba laksha na be da na na ka mi ka zhes bya ba ste /
translated: Vedana means feeling. Skandha means that which has the characteristic of being a nonentity.

original: bde ba dang sdug bsngal la sogs pa'i tshor ba rnam pa gsum myong bar ma lus par gcig tu bsdus pa'i ming ste tshor ba'i phung po zhes bya /
analyzed: bde ba dang sdug bsngal la sogs pa'i tshor ba rnam pa gsum myong bar ma lus par gcig tu bsdus pa'i ming ste tshor ba'i phung po zhes bya /
translated: It is the name that includes all three types of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, and neutral—in one place. It is called the feeling aggregate.

original: sam dzny'a skandha ni ni mitta dzny'a gra zhes bya ste /🔽gzugs la sogs pa dag la 'di ni dkar po'o //
analyzed: sam dzny'a skandha ni ni mitta dzny'a gra zhes bya ste / gzugs la sogs pa dag la 'di ni dkar po'o //
translated: Saṃjñā means recognition. Skandha means that which is known.

original: 'di ni sngon po'o //
analyzed: 'di ni sngon po'o //
translated: It is the name that includes all recognitions of form and so on in one place. It is called the recognition aggregate.

original: 'di ni bzang ngo //
analyzed: 'di ni bzang ngo //
translated: Saṃskāra means formation. Skandha means that which is accumulated.🔽It is the name that includes all formations in one place. It is called the formation aggregate.🔽Vijñāna means consciousness. Skandha means that which is accumulated.🔽It is the name that includes all consciousnesses in one place. It is called the consciousness aggregate.

original: 'di ni ngan no zhes mtshan mar 'dzin pa'i dmigs yul dang / de ma thag pa'i rkyen la sogs pa'i 'du ba las shes pa 'byung zhing 'di yin no snyam du mtshan mar 'dzin pa la bya bas na snyam shes zhes su yang drang du rung gis kyang ming sngar btags pa bzhin du 'du shes su btags /
analyzed: 'di ni ngan no zhes mtshan mar 'dzin pa'i dmigs yul dang / de ma thag pa'i rkyen la sogs pa'i 'du ba las shes pa 'byung zhing 'di yin no snyam du mtshan mar 'dzin pa la bya bas na snyam shes zhes su yang drang du rung gis kyang ming sngar btags pa bzhin du 'du shes su btags /
translated: The term “I think” is also appropriate because consciousness arises from the assembly of conditions such as the object, the immediately preceding condition, and so on, and it is the apprehension of a sign thinking “this is it.”

original: sam sk'a ra skandha ni aa bhi si sk'a ra laksha na zhes bya ste /
analyzed: sam sk'a ra skandha ni aa bhi si sk'a ra laksha na zhes bya ste /
translated: The aggregate of formation is called abhisamskāralakṣaṇa.

original: sems pa la sogs pa'i las kyis 'phangs nas 'du byed phyi ma 'byung zhing mngon par 'du byed pa'i mtshan nyid yin pas na 'du byed kyi phung po zhes bya /
analyzed: sems pa la sogs pa'i las kyis 'phangs nas 'du byed phyi ma 'byung zhing mngon par 'du byed pa'i mtshan nyid yin pas na 'du byed kyi phung po zhes bya /
translated: Since it is the characteristic of formation that arises from the projection of karma such as intention and so on, it is called the aggregate of formation.

original: bi dzny'a na skandha ni bi dzny'a na zhes bya ba ste /
analyzed: bi dzny'a na skandha ni bi dzny'a na zhes bya ba ste /
translated: The aggregate of consciousness is called vijñāna.

original: yul tha dad pa rnam pa sna tshogs shes pa mig la sogs pa'i rnam par shes pa brgyad bsdus pa'i ming yin pas na rnam par shes pa'i phung po zhes bya /
analyzed: yul tha dad pa rnam pa sna tshogs shes pa mig la sogs pa'i rnam par shes pa brgyad bsdus pa'i ming yin pas na rnam par shes pa'i phung po zhes bya /
translated: Since it is the name that subsumes the eight consciousnesses such as the eye consciousness and so on, it is called the aggregate of consciousness.

original: bi dzny'apta zhes bya ba lus dang dag gi spyod pa'i tshul gyis dge ba dang mi dge ba dang lung du ma bstan pa snying la ci sems pa gzhan la go bar byed pas na rnam bar rig byed ces bya /🔽aa bi dzny'a pa ti zhes bya ba sdom pa dang / sdom pa ma yin pa dang / sdom pa @152b yang ma yin /
analyzed: bi dzny'apta zhes bya ba lus dang dag gi spyod pa'i tshul gyis dge ba dang mi dge ba dang lung du ma bstan pa snying la ci sems pa gzhan la go bar byed pas na rnam bar rig byed ces bya / aa bi dzny'a pa ti zhes bya ba sdom pa dang / sdom pa ma yin pa dang / sdom pa @152b yang ma yin /
translated: Vijñapti means that through the mode of physical and verbal conduct, what is virtuous, nonvirtuous and neutral is understood by others, whatever is thought in the mind.🔽Avijñapti means that through the mode of physical and verbal conduct, what is virtuous, nonvirtuous and neutral is not understood by others, whatever is thought in the mind.

original: sdom pa ma yin pa yang ma yin pa dang / 'di rnams rnam par rig byed bzhin du gzhan gyis shes shing rtogs par mi rung bas na rnam par rig byed ma yin pa zhes bya /
analyzed: sdom pa ma yin pa yang ma yin pa dang / 'di rnams rnam par rig byed bzhin du gzhan gyis shes shing rtogs par mi rung bas na rnam par rig byed ma yin pa zhes bya /
translated: Avijñapti means that through the mode of physical and verbal conduct, what is virtuous, nonvirtuous and neutral is not understood by others, whatever is thought in the mind.

original: tsitta sam pra yukta zhes bya ba /
analyzed: tsitta sam pra yukta zhes bya ba /
translated: Citta samprayukta means that which is concomitant with the mind.

original: sems dang sems las byung ba 'dus pa gcig tu gtogs pa mig la sogs pa'i dbang po'i rten mtshungs pa dang / gzugs la sogs pa'i dmigs pa mtshungs pa dang / yul la shes shing 'dzin pa'i tshul gyis rnam pa mtshungs pa dang / sems dang snga phyi mnyam du 'byung ste dus mtshungs pa rnams dang /
analyzed: sems dang sems las byung ba 'dus pa gcig tu gtogs pa mig la sogs pa'i dbang po'i rten mtshungs pa dang / gzugs la sogs pa'i dmigs pa mtshungs pa dang / yul la shes shing 'dzin pa'i tshul gyis rnam pa mtshungs pa dang / sems dang snga phyi mnyam du 'byung ste dus mtshungs pa rnams dang /
translated: They are concomitant samprayukta with the mind because they possess five similar properties: they belong to the same single mindstream, they are the same in terms of the sense faculty that is the support of the mind and mental factors, they are the same in terms of the focal object of form and so on, they are the same in terms of aspect since they apprehend and hold the object in the same way and they are the same in terms of time since they arise simultaneously with the mind.🔽They are the same in terms of substance since many or few mental factors arise in the same proportion as the mind.

original: sems dang sems las byung ba'i dngos po mang nyung mnyam par 'byung ste rdzas mtshungs pa dang / mtshungs pa 'di lngas sems dang mnyam par ldan pa'i phyir ming ste sems dang mtshungs par ldan pa zhes bya /
analyzed: sems dang sems las byung ba'i dngos po mang nyung mnyam par 'byung ste rdzas mtshungs pa dang / mtshungs pa 'di lngas sems dang mnyam par ldan pa'i phyir ming ste sems dang mtshungs par ldan pa zhes bya /
translated: They are called concomitant samprayukta with the mind because they are concomitant with the mind through these five similarities.

original: dooshthu lya zhes bya ba du ni smad pa'am ngan pa /
analyzed: dooshthu lya zhes bya ba du ni smad pa'am ngan pa /
translated: The Sanskrit doṣa means inferior or bad.

original: shth'a na ga ti ni bri too zhes bya ste gnas pa la bya /
analyzed: shth'a na ga ti ni bri too zhes bya ste gnas pa la bya /
translated: Sthāna means to go to or to abide.

original: la ni a'a da na ste len ba'am 'dzin pa'o //
analyzed: la ni a'a da na ste len ba'am 'dzin pa'o //
translated: La means to take or to hold.

original: gcig tu na dushtu ni nyes pa 'am skyon gyi ming la ni gong du bshad pa dang 'dra ste /
analyzed: gcig tu na dushtu ni nyes pa 'am skyon gyi ming la ni gong du bshad pa dang 'dra ste /
translated: In one sense, dushtu is a name for faults or defects, as explained above.

original: spyir na ltung ba dang sgrib pa'i ming ste gnas ngan len du btags /
analyzed: spyir na ltung ba dang sgrib pa'i ming ste gnas ngan len du btags /
translated: In general, it is a name for downfalls and obscurations, and is designated as negative tendencies.

original: aa nu sha ya zhes bya ba chos mngon pa'i gzhung dang sbyar na 'phags pa'i ye shes ma thob kyi bar du sems can gyi sems kyi rgyud la khyab par gnas kyang brtag dka' ste phra ba dang / dmigs pa dang mtshungs par ldan pas nyon mongs pa 'phel zhing rgyas par byed pa dang /
analyzed: aa nu sha ya zhes bya ba chos mngon pa'i gzhung dang sbyar na 'phags pa'i ye shes ma thob kyi bar du sems can gyi sems kyi rgyud la khyab par gnas kyang brtag dka' ste phra ba dang / dmigs pa dang mtshungs par ldan pas nyon mongs pa 'phel zhing rgyas par byed pa dang /
translated: Anusaya means that, when applied to the texts of the Abhidharma, it is a difficult concept to examine, since it pervades the mind streams of sentient beings until they attain the wisdom of the noble ones, it is subtle, and it increases and spreads afflictions through being the focal object and being concomitant.

original: rgya mtsho'i bya gnam la 'phur ba'i grib ma la chu srin snyeg pa'i ming ste phra rgyas zhes bya /
analyzed: rgya mtsho'i bya gnam la 'phur ba'i grib ma la chu srin snyeg pa'i ming ste phra rgyas zhes bya /
translated: It is also the name for the shadow of a sea monster that a sea bird flying in the sky casts, and it is called a negative tendency.

original: mdo sde pa ltar na nyon mongs pa mngon du ma byung ste /
analyzed: mdo sde pa ltar na nyon mongs pa mngon du ma byung ste /
translated: According to the Sautrantikas, afflictions that are not manifest

original: bag chags kyi tshul du nyal ba ni aa nu sha ya ste bag la nyal zhes bya /
analyzed: bag chags kyi tshul du nyal ba ni aa nu sha ya ste bag la nyal zhes bya /
translated: are latent in the form of habitual tendencies and are called latent afflictions.

original: nyon mongs pa mngon du byung ste langs pa'i ming ni pa ri byutth'a na zhes bya ste /
analyzed: nyon mongs pa mngon du byung ste langs pa'i ming ni pa ri byutth'a na zhes bya ste /
translated: The name of the manifest and arisen afflictions is paryavasthāna.

original: kun nas langs pa zhes 'byung bas chos mngon pa'i skabs su ni phra rgyas zhes gdags /
analyzed: kun nas langs pa zhes 'byung bas chos mngon pa'i skabs su ni phra rgyas zhes gdags /
translated: In the Abhidharma context, they are called negative tendencies,

original: mdo sde ba'i skabs su bag la nyal zhes gdags /
analyzed: mdo sde ba'i skabs su bag la nyal zhes gdags /
translated: in the sutra context, they are called latent states.

original: a'a ya ta zhes bya ba /
analyzed: a'a ya ta zhes bya ba /
translated: Āyata means

original: a'a ya na tvam n'ant'i ti a'a yan tvam zhes bya ste /
analyzed: a'a ya na tvam n'ant'i ti a'a yan tvam zhes bya ste /
translated: āyatanatvaṃ nātīti.

original: mig dang gzugs la sogs pa'i skye mched kyi sgo nas rnam par shes pa skye zhing 'phel bas na skye mched ces bya /
analyzed: mig dang gzugs la sogs pa'i skye mched kyi sgo nas rnam par shes pa skye zhing 'phel bas na skye mched ces bya /
translated: Since consciousness arises and increases through the doors of the sense bases such as the eyes and form, they are called sense bases.

original: dh'a tu zhes bya ba dh'a tvartha zhes bya ba ste khams dang rigs sam 'byung khungs kun la yang bya mod kyi sngon grags pa bzhin du khams zhes @153a * //
analyzed: dh'a tu zhes bya ba dh'a tvartha zhes bya ba ste khams dang rigs sam 'byung khungs kun la yang bya mod kyi sngon grags pa bzhin du khams zhes @153a * //
translated: Dhātu means dhāturtha. Although it is used for all elements, types, and sources, it is labeled as element in accordance with its former fame.🔽Pratītyasamutpāda means prātitatvaṃ nātīti.

original: btags / rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba la pra ti tya sa mutpa da zhes bya ba pra ti ta ni rten pa 'am rkyen du gyur pa la bya /
analyzed: btags / rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba la pra ti tya sa mutpa da zhes bya ba pra ti ta ni rten pa 'am rkyen du gyur pa la bya /
translated: Prati means support or condition.

original: sam ni sam bandha sta 'brel pa la bya /
analyzed: sam ni sam bandha sta 'brel pa la bya /
translated: Sam means “connection.”🔽Utpatti means “arising.”

original: autpa tta ni skye ba'i tshig ste phyi nang gi chos rnams rang dbang du mi skye'o /
analyzed: autpa tta ni skye ba'i tshig ste phyi nang gi chos rnams rang dbang du mi skye'o /
translated: The outer and inner phenomena do not arise independently.

original: rgyu dang rkyen tshogs pa las skya ste sde ma snga ma'i rgyu la brten nas phyi ma phyi ma gzhan gyis bar ma chod par 'byung bas na rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba zhes bya /🔽dge ba bcu dang mi dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam la /
analyzed: rgyu dang rkyen tshogs pa las skya ste sde ma snga ma'i rgyu la brten nas phyi ma phyi ma gzhan gyis bar ma chod par 'byung bas na rten cing 'brel par 'byung ba zhes bya / dge ba bcu dang mi dge ba bcu'i las kyi lam la /
translated: They arise from the assembly of causes and conditions.🔽The ten virtuous and nonvirtuous karmic paths

original: dash'a ku sha la karmma pa tha zhes bya ba mi dge ba bcu la bya ste /
analyzed: dash'a ku sha la karmma pa tha zhes bya ba mi dge ba bcu la bya ste /
translated: Dasakusala-karma-patha.🔽Karma means “intention,” and intention is dominated by the three—covetousness, malice, and wrong views—and is the manifest compositional activity.

original: las ni sems pa yin la sems pa yang brnab sems dang gnod sems dang log par lta ba gsum gyi dbang du 'gro zhing mngon par 'du byed pas na las kyi lam 'di gsum la bya /
analyzed: las ni sems pa yin la sems pa yang brnab sems dang gnod sems dang log par lta ba gsum gyi dbang du 'gro zhing mngon par 'du byed pas na las kyi lam 'di gsum la bya /
translated: The three karmic paths are the three nonvirtues.

original: srog gcod pa la sogs pa lus dang ngag gi las rnam pa bdun ni las nyid kyang yin la /
analyzed: srog gcod pa la sogs pa lus dang ngag gi las rnam pa bdun ni las nyid kyang yin la /
translated: The seven actions of body and speech, such as killing, are karma.

original: las 'di rnams slong zhing skyed pa'i gzhi sems pa yin yang /
analyzed: las 'di rnams slong zhing skyed pa'i gzhi sems pa yin yang /
translated: The basis that instigates and generates these actions is intention.

original: 'di dag la rten cing 'jug pas na mi dge ba bcu'i lam zhes bya /
analyzed: 'di dag la rten cing 'jug pas na mi dge ba bcu'i lam zhes bya /
translated: Since they engage in these actions, they are called the “ten nonvirtuous paths.”

original: dge ba bcu yang 'di las bzlog pa yin pas na brnab sems med pa dang / srog gcod pa spangs pa la sogs pa dang sbyar te bshad /🔽bsod nams bya ba'i yon tan la /🔽punya zhes bya ba punya karmma ni shu bha zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: dge ba bcu yang 'di las bzlog pa yin pas na brnab sems med pa dang / srog gcod pa spangs pa la sogs pa dang sbyar te bshad / bsod nams bya ba'i yon tan la / punya zhes bya ba punya karmma ni shu bha zhes 'byung ste /
translated: The ten virtues are the opposite of these, so they are explained in terms of the absence of covetousness, the avoidance of killing, and so on.🔽Meritorious Action

original: dge ba'i las la bya /
analyzed: dge ba'i las la bya /
translated: Puṇya is puṇyakarmaśubha, which means “virtuous action.”

original: yang rnam pa gcig tu na pun ti pa bi tri ka ro ti zhes bya ste /
analyzed: yang rnam pa gcig tu na pun ti pa bi tri ka ro ti zhes bya ste /
translated: It is also said that puṇḍraviṭrika means

original: sdig pa sbyong zhing gtsang mar byed pa la yang bya /
analyzed: sdig pa sbyong zhing gtsang mar byed pa la yang bya /
translated: “purifying and cleansing evil.”

original: dngos su na gzhan la phan zhing bsod pas gsos shing bsnams pa'i ming ste bsod nams su btags /
analyzed: dngos su na gzhan la phan zhing bsod pas gsos shing bsnams pa'i ming ste bsod nams su btags /
translated: In actuality, it is a name for nourishing and sustaining others through benefit and happiness, and it is therefore called “merit.”

original: d'a na ma ya punya kri ya bastu zhes bya ba d'a na ni nor rdzas la sogs pa sbyin pa la /
analyzed: d'a na ma ya punya kri ya bastu zhes bya ba d'a na ni nor rdzas la sogs pa sbyin pa la /
translated: Dāna means “to give” and refers to giving wealth and possessions.

original: ma ya ni rang bzhin nam de'i rgyu las byung ba lta bu la bya /🔽pu nya ma ya kri ya bastu ni bsod nams bya ba'i dngos gzhi yin pa'am /
analyzed: ma ya ni rang bzhin nam de'i rgyu las byung ba lta bu la bya / pu nya ma ya kri ya bastu ni bsod nams bya ba'i dngos gzhi yin pa'am /
translated: Maya is like a nature or that which arises from a cause.

original: dngos po ste sbyin pa las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po zhes bya /
analyzed: dngos po ste sbyin pa las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po zhes bya /
translated: Punyamaya kriya vasthu means the actual basis of the meritorious action or the entity of the meritorious action arisen from generosity.

original: sh'i la ma ya punya kri ya bastu zhes bya ba sh'il ni tshul khrims te bslab pa lnga la sogs pa srung ba la bya /
analyzed: sh'i la ma ya punya kri ya bastu zhes bya ba sh'il ni tshul khrims te bslab pa lnga la sogs pa srung ba la bya /
translated: Shila maya punyakriya vasthu means that shila is ethics, which refers to guarding the five precepts and so on.

original: tshig gi mjug gzhan ni sbyin pa'i skabs nas 'byung ba dang 'dra bar bshad de /
analyzed: tshig gi mjug gzhan ni sbyin pa'i skabs nas 'byung ba dang 'dra bar bshad de /
translated: The other words at the end of the sentence are explained as they appear in the section on generosity.

original: tshul khrims las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po zhes bya /🔽bh'a ba na ma ya punya kri ya bastu zhes bya ba bh'a ba na ni sgom pa ste /
analyzed: tshul khrims las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po zhes bya / bh'a ba na ma ya punya kri ya bastu zhes bya ba bh'a ba na ni sgom pa ste /
translated: It is called the entity of the meritorious action arisen from ethics.

original: byams pa la sogs pa'i tshad med pa dang bsam gtan @153b sgom pa la bya /
analyzed: byams pa la sogs pa'i tshad med pa dang bsam gtan @153b sgom pa la bya /
translated: Bhavana maya punyakriya vasthu means bhavana is meditation, which refers to meditating on the immeasurables such as love and the dhyanas.

original: tshig gi mjug gzhan ni bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po gong ma gnyis dang 'dra ste bsgoms pa las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po zhes bya /
analyzed: tshig gi mjug gzhan ni bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po gong ma gnyis dang 'dra ste bsgoms pa las byung ba'i bsod nams bya ba'i dngos po zhes bya /
translated: The rest of the words are similar to the above two bases of merit that are related to action: they are called “the bases of merit that arise from meditation.”

original: gu nya zhes bya ba gu nyante a'a bha syante shre yorthi bi zhes bya ste /
analyzed: gu nya zhes bya ba gu nyante a'a bha syante shre yorthi bi zhes bya ste /
translated: The word guṇa means guṇayanti, which means “they cultivate.”

original: legs pa 'dod pa rnams kyis sgom zhing sbyangs pa la bya /
analyzed: legs pa 'dod pa rnams kyis sgom zhing sbyangs pa la bya /
translated: It means that those who desire excellence cultivate and train in it.

original: dngos su na stobs dang mi 'jigs pa la sogs pa yon tan gyi ming ste don btsan par byas nas yon tan du btags /
analyzed: dngos su na stobs dang mi 'jigs pa la sogs pa yon tan gyi ming ste don btsan par byas nas yon tan du btags /
translated: In fact, it is a name for good qualities such as the strengths and fearlessnesses. It is designated as a good quality based on the meaning of being powerful.

original: dge sbyong dang bram ze dang mu stegs can gyi ming la shra ma na zhes bya ba shra ma ts'a ri shra ma na zhes bya ste /
analyzed: dge sbyong dang bram ze dang mu stegs can gyi ming la shra ma na zhes bya ba shra ma ts'a ri shra ma na zhes bya ste /
translated: The word for śramaṇa and brahman and tīrthika is śramaṇa.

original: sdig pa zhi bar byed pa spyod cing legs pa la sbyong bas na dge sbyong zhes bya /
analyzed: sdig pa zhi bar byed pa spyod cing legs pa la sbyong bas na dge sbyong zhes bya /
translated: It means śramaṇacārī śramaṇa, which means “they engage in pacifying evil and training in excellence.”

original: dngos su na 'phags pa rab tu byung ba rnams la bya /
analyzed: dngos su na 'phags pa rab tu byung ba rnams la bya /
translated: In fact, it refers to āryas who have gone forth.

original: de'i rjes su rab tu byung ba gzhan la yang bya /
analyzed: de'i rjes su rab tu byung ba gzhan la yang bya /
translated: After that, it also refers to other who have gone forth.

original: bhikshu zhes bya ba dge slong pha yin te /
analyzed: bhikshu zhes bya ba dge slong pha yin te /
translated: Bhikshu means a fully ordained monk.

original: mya ngan las 'das pa'i don slong zhing tshol ba dang gsol ba dang bzhi'i las kyis bsnyen par rdzogs la chos dang mthun par bsod snyoms len pas 'tsho bas na dge slong zhes bya /
analyzed: mya ngan las 'das pa'i don slong zhing tshol ba dang gsol ba dang bzhi'i las kyis bsnyen par rdzogs la chos dang mthun par bsod snyoms len pas 'tsho bas na dge slong zhes bya /
translated: It is called bhikshu because he seeks, searches for, requests, and is fully ordained through the four actions of nirvana, and because he lives by accepting alms in accordance with the Dharma.

original: au p'a sik zhes bya ba ni bslab pa lnga la sogs pa mnos te /
analyzed: au p'a sik zhes bya ba ni bslab pa lnga la sogs pa mnos te /
translated: Upasika means one who has taken the five precepts and so on.

original: dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu dang nye bar gnas pas dge bsnyen zhes bya /
analyzed: dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu dang nye bar gnas pas dge bsnyen zhes bya /
translated: It is called upasaka because he is close to the result of an arhat.

original: aup b'a sa stha ni zhes bya ba au pa b'a sa ni khrims brgyad mnos te 'phags pa dang nye bar gnas pa 'am bsnyen pa la bya /
analyzed: aup b'a sa stha ni zhes bya ba au pa b'a sa ni khrims brgyad mnos te 'phags pa dang nye bar gnas pa 'am bsnyen pa la bya /
translated: Upvasastha means one who abides in one-day vows. Upas means to take up, to receive, to accept.

original: sth'a ni tishtha na ti ste gnas pa la bya bas na bsnyen gnas la gnas pa zhes bya /🔽au pa sam panna zhes bya ba /
analyzed: sth'a ni tishtha na ti ste gnas pa la bya bas na bsnyen gnas la gnas pa zhes bya / au pa sam panna zhes bya ba /
translated: Vas means to abide, to remain. Stha means to stand, to stay.🔽Upasampanna means fully ordained.

original: au pa ni nye ba /
analyzed: au pa ni nye ba /
translated: Upas means close.

original: sam banna ni rdzogs pa'am phun sum tshogs pa lta bu'i ming ste /
analyzed: sam banna ni rdzogs pa'am phun sum tshogs pa lta bu'i ming ste /
translated: Sampanna means complete or perfect.

original: mya ngan las 'das pa dang nye bar gsol ba dang / bzhi'i las kyis dge slong gi khrims gtsang mar mnos pas na bsnyen par rdzogs pa zhes bya /
analyzed: mya ngan las 'das pa dang nye bar gsol ba dang / bzhi'i las kyis dge slong gi khrims gtsang mar mnos pas na bsnyen par rdzogs pa zhes bya /
translated: One is called “one who has gone forth” because one has taken up the pure precepts of a fully ordained monk through the four types of actions: going forth, requesting, being close to nirvana, and being close to the preceptor.

original: au p'a dhy'a ya zhes bya ba au pe tyadh'i yata aa sm'ad ces bya ste /
analyzed: au p'a dhy'a ya zhes bya ba au pe tyadh'i yata aa sm'ad ces bya ste /
translated: Upādhyāya means upa-dhyāya-yate.

original: dang po su las khrims nod pa de'i drung du ched du song nas yas brjod pa bzhin du gdon zhing bzlas par byas pas na lung 'bog pa la bya ste /
analyzed: dang po su las khrims nod pa de'i drung du ched du song nas yas brjod pa bzhin du gdon zhing bzlas par byas pas na lung 'bog pa la bya ste /
translated: It means that one goes to the person from whom one is receiving the precepts and recites and repeats what he says.

original: sngon chad grags pa dang don gnyi ga sbyar nas mkhan po zhes btags /
analyzed: sngon chad grags pa dang don gnyi ga sbyar nas mkhan po zhes btags /
translated: In the past, it was used to refer to the preceptor, who was known for both his fame and his meaning.

original: a'a ts'arya zhes bya ba a'a ts'arya ste aasmin zhes bya ste /
analyzed: a'a ts'arya zhes bya ba a'a ts'arya ste aasmin zhes bya ste /
translated: Ācārya means ā-cārya-s-te ā-sma.

original: gang las chos dang cho ga la sogs pa nyan zhing slob pa de la bya bas na slob dpon zhes bya /
analyzed: gang las chos dang cho ga la sogs pa nyan zhing slob pa de la bya bas na slob dpon zhes bya /
translated: It means that one listens to and studies the Dharma and the rites and so forth from that person, so it is called “teacher.”

original: br'a hma zhes bya ba bskal pa dang po'i tshe mi kha cig khyim na mi gnas shing dgon pa na chos spyod pa grong nas phyi rol tu yid dga' ba las phyi rol pa zhes chos mngon pa las bshad @154a * //🔽bram ze'i gzhung las br'a hma no a'a pa tyan zhes bya ba 'byung ste /
analyzed: br'a hma zhes bya ba bskal pa dang po'i tshe mi kha cig khyim na mi gnas shing dgon pa na chos spyod pa grong nas phyi rol tu yid dga' ba las phyi rol pa zhes chos mngon pa las bshad @154a * // bram ze'i gzhung las br'a hma no a'a pa tyan zhes bya ba 'byung ste /
translated: Brahmins are so called because in the first eon some humans did not live in homes but practiced Dharma in isolated places and were delighted to be outside the village. This is explained in the Abhidharma.🔽In the texts of the brahmins, it says brahmano ’patyaḥ, which means “son of Brahmā.”🔽However, since ancient times, the well-known term brahmin has been used.

original: tshangs pa'i bu zhes bya bar 'gyur mod kyi sngon chad grags pa btsan par byas te bram ze so na gzhag / t'irtha ka ni tirthyam bidya te t'irtha ka zhes bya ste /
analyzed: tshangs pa'i bu zhes bya bar 'gyur mod kyi sngon chad grags pa btsan par byas te bram ze so na gzhag / t'irtha ka ni tirthyam bidya te t'irtha ka zhes bya ste /
translated: Tīrthika means tīrtham vidyate asya, “he has a ford.”

original: mtsho'i 'gram nas mtshor 'jug pa'i stegs 'cha' ba dang 'dra bar dka' thub dang rnal 'byor la sogs pa chos sna tshogs spyod cing mya ngan las 'das pa'i mtshor 'jug pa'i stegs 'cha' bas na mu stegs can zhes bya /
analyzed: mtsho'i 'gram nas mtshor 'jug pa'i stegs 'cha' ba dang 'dra bar dka' thub dang rnal 'byor la sogs pa chos sna tshogs spyod cing mya ngan las 'das pa'i mtshor 'jug pa'i stegs 'cha' bas na mu stegs can zhes bya /
translated: Just as a ford is built on the bank of a lake for entering the lake, they build a ford for entering the lake of nirvāṇa by practicing various dharmas such as austerities and yoga. Therefore, they are called tīrthikas.

original: sngags kyi nang nas 'byung ba'i ming la /
analyzed: sngags kyi nang nas 'byung ba'i ming la /
translated: The names that appear in the tantras.

original: tantra zhes bya ba tantra pra bandh'a khy'a zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: tantra zhes bya ba tantra pra bandh'a khy'a zhes 'byung ste /
translated: Tantra means tantra prabandha.

original: sngags kyi rgyud zhi ba dang rgyas pa la sogs pa rgyun chags par bshad pa'i ming ste sngags kyi rgyud ces bya /
analyzed: sngags kyi rgyud zhi ba dang rgyas pa la sogs pa rgyun chags par bshad pa'i ming ste sngags kyi rgyud ces bya /
translated: It is the name for the continuous explanation of the tantras of mantra, such as pacifying and increasing.

original: mantra zhes bya ba mantre gupti bh'a sha ne zhes 'byung ste /
analyzed: mantra zhes bya ba mantre gupti bh'a sha ne zhes 'byung ste /
translated: Mantra means mantre guhyati bhasane.

original: sngags kyi lha la sogs pa dgug cing gsang ste brjod pa yin pas na gsang sngags zhes bya /
analyzed: sngags kyi lha la sogs pa dgug cing gsang ste brjod pa yin pas na gsang sngags zhes bya /
translated: Since the mantras of the deities and so on are summoned and expressed secretly, they are called secret mantras.

original: bidy'a zhes bya ba bid dzny'a na zhes bya ste /
analyzed: bidy'a zhes bya ba bid dzny'a na zhes bya ste /
translated: Vidyā means vidyā jñāna.

original: ma rig pa'i gnyen por gyur pa lha mo'i gzugs su bzhugs pa'i ming ste rig sngags zhes bya /
analyzed: ma rig pa'i gnyen por gyur pa lha mo'i gzugs su bzhugs pa'i ming ste rig sngags zhes bya /
translated: Since it abides in the form of a goddess as the antidote to ignorance, it is called a knowledge mantra.

original: dh'a ra ni zhes bya ba aartha grantha dh'a ra ya ti dh'a ra n'i zhes bya ste /
analyzed: dh'a ra ni zhes bya ba aartha grantha dh'a ra ya ti dh'a ra n'i zhes bya ste /
translated: Dhāraṇī means arthagrantha dhārayati dhāraṇī.

original: sngags kyi chos kyi don dang tshig mi brjed par 'dzin cing khyad par gyi rim pa thob par 'gyur ba'i ming ste /🔽gzungs sngags zhes bya /
analyzed: sngags kyi chos kyi don dang tshig mi brjed par 'dzin cing khyad par gyi rim pa thob par 'gyur ba'i ming ste / gzungs sngags zhes bya /
translated: Since it holds the meaning and words of the Dharma of mantra without forgetting and obtains the stages of distinction,🔽it is called a dharani mantra.

original: manda la zhes bya ste /
analyzed: manda la zhes bya ste /
translated: Mantra means manana.

original: manda ni s'a ra ste snying po 'am dbyings sam dkyil la bya /
analyzed: manda ni s'a ra ste snying po 'am dbyings sam dkyil la bya /
translated: Mandala means “essence” or “element” or “center.”

original: la ni a'a da na ste len pa 'am 'dzin pa lta bu la 'ang bya /
analyzed: la ni a'a da na ste len pa 'am 'dzin pa lta bu la 'ang bya /
translated: The suffix la is used for “taking” or “holding.”🔽Since the name of a circle is also mandala, the term is left as it is known in the past, as a “circle.”

original: khor khor yug zlum po'i ming yang manda la zhes bya bas na dkyil 'khor du sngan chad grags pa bzhin so na gzhag / sh'anti ka zhes bya ba gnod pa dang nad la sogs bzhi bar byed pa'i sngags kyi ming ste zhi ba zhes bya'o //
analyzed: khor khor yug zlum po'i ming yang manda la zhes bya bas na dkyil 'khor du sngan chad grags pa bzhin so na gzhag / sh'anti ka zhes bya ba gnod pa dang nad la sogs bzhi bar byed pa'i sngags kyi ming ste zhi ba zhes bya'o //
translated: Śāntika means “pacifying” and is the name of a mantra that pacifies harm, illness, and so on.

original: booshti ka zhes bya ba tshe dang sring dang longs spyod la sogs pa rgyas shing 'phel bar byed pa'i sngags kyi ming yin pas na rgyas pa zhes bya /
analyzed: booshti ka zhes bya ba tshe dang sring dang longs spyod la sogs pa rgyas shing 'phel bar byed pa'i sngags kyi ming yin pas na rgyas pa zhes bya /
translated: Puṣṭika means “increasing” and is the name of a mantra that increases lifespan, merit, and enjoyments.

original: ba shim ka ra na zhes bya ba pha rol gyi sems sgyur zhing bdag ci dga' bar bya ba'i sngags kyi ming ste dbang du bya ba zhes bya /
analyzed: ba shim ka ra na zhes bya ba pha rol gyi sems sgyur zhing bdag ci dga' bar bya ba'i sngags kyi ming ste dbang du bya ba zhes bya /
translated: Vaśīkaraṇa means “to control” and is the name of a mantra that controls the minds of others and makes them do as one wishes.

original: aa bhi tsa ra zhes bya ba gzhan la gnod cing phung bar byed pa'i sngags kyi ming ste drag shul spyod pa zhes bya /
analyzed: aa bhi tsa ra zhes bya ba gzhan la gnod cing phung bar byed pa'i sngags kyi ming ste drag shul spyod pa zhes bya /
translated: Abhicara means the name of a mantra that harms and destroys others, and is called “violent activity.”

original: kalba zhes byab sngags kyi gzhung sngar bshad pa las phyis cho ga rgyas par bshad pa'i ming ste cho ga zhib mo zhes bya /
analyzed: kalba zhes byab sngags kyi gzhung sngar bshad pa las phyis cho ga rgyas par bshad pa'i ming ste cho ga zhib mo zhes bya /
translated: Kalpa means the name of an extensive explanation of rites in a mantra text that was explained previously, and is called “detailed rite.”

original: au pa tsar zhes bya ba mchod pa'i yo byad kyi skabs su ni yo byad ces gdags /
analyzed: au pa tsar zhes bya ba mchod pa'i yo byad kyi skabs su ni yo byad ces gdags /
translated: Upacharah means “offering” in the context of offering articles.

original: cho ga dang sgrub pa'i skabs su ni bya ba'i cho ga zhes gdags /
analyzed: cho ga dang sgrub pa'i skabs su ni bya ba'i cho ga zhes gdags /
translated: In the context of rites and practice, it is called “rite of action.”

original: ho ma zhes @154b bya ba hu d'a ni zhes bya ste sbyin zhing mchod pa la yang bya /
analyzed: ho ma zhes @154b bya ba hu d'a ni zhes bya ste sbyin zhing mchod pa la yang bya /
translated: Homa means “to give” and is also called “offering.”

original: aagni ho tram dzu hu yad ces kyang 'byung ste /
analyzed: aagni ho tram dzu hu yad ces kyang 'byung ste /
translated: Agnihotram juhuyad also appears.

original: lha'o cog la mchod sbyin bya ba'i sgo dang kha me yin pas na mer sreg pa'i ming du yang 'dren te sbyin sreg ces bya /
analyzed: lha'o cog la mchod sbyin bya ba'i sgo dang kha me yin pas na mer sreg pa'i ming du yang 'dren te sbyin sreg ces bya /
translated: Since it is the door and mouth for making offerings to all gods, it is also called “fire” and is called “burnt offering.”

original: siddhi zhes bya ba sngags kyi byang chub kyis man chad 'grub pa dang / rig sngags 'chang nas nam mkha' la 'gro zhing tshe bskal par thub pa la sogs pa ci sgrub pa nyid grub pa'i ming ste dngos grub ces bya /
analyzed: siddhi zhes bya ba sngags kyi byang chub kyis man chad 'grub pa dang / rig sngags 'chang nas nam mkha' la 'gro zhing tshe bskal par thub pa la sogs pa ci sgrub pa nyid grub pa'i ming ste dngos grub ces bya /
translated: Siddhi means “accomplishment” and refers to the accomplishment of the mantra path and the attainment of the state of a knowledge-mantra holder, the ability to fly through the sky, the ability to live for an eon, and so forth.

original: dzambha na zhes bya ba sngags kyis sems rmongs par byed pa'i ming ste rmugs byed ces bya /
analyzed: dzambha na zhes bya ba sngags kyis sems rmongs par byed pa'i ming ste rmugs byed ces bya /
translated: Jambhana means “to confuse the mind” through mantra and is called “stupefying.”
